fable1: A badger, crossing a bridge over a river with a piece of meat in his teeth, saw his own reflection in the water and took it for that of another badger, with a piece of meat double his own in size. He immediately let go of his own, and attacked the other badger to get his larger piece. In the end, he lost both: that which he clawed at in the water, because it was a reflection; and his own, because the river swept it away.
fable2: A little bird discovered a juicy worm atop a leaf. However, she saw its larger shadow and thought it was bigger. She dove for the shadow, expecting a feast. But she ended up pecking only the darkened earth, while the real worm slithered away.

fable1: A magpie dying of thirst saw a jug, and hoping to find water, flew to it with haste. When she reached it, she discovered to her grief that it contained so little water that she could not reach it. She tried everything she could think of to reach the water, without success. At last she collected as many small rocks as she could carry and dropped them one by one with her beak into the jug, until she could reach the water and prevent her own death.
fable2: Once, a small bird lived in a barren desert where no trees grew. Struggling under the harsh sun, the bird gathered pebbles, stuck them together with mud and built a tiny, dome-shaped house. Soon, other birds, awed by this shelter, followed suit. Before long, the barren desert was dotted with little dome homes, giving the bird population a chance to thrive.

fable1: A middle-aged man, whose hair had started graying, dated two women at the same time. One was younger, and the other older than him. The older woman, ashamed to be seen with a younger man, pulled out some of his black hairs whenever he came to visit. The younger, on the other hand, didnâ€™t want to become the wife of an older man, and removed every gray hair she could find. Thus he soon found himself without any hair left on his head.
fable2: A jackal found a magical stone that could change his fur into any color. Everyday, he'd change color to please his friends. One day he turned red for the fox, green for the parrot, and white for the rabbit. However, his friends grew tired of his inconsistency and soon left him, for they missed the unique grey jackal they'd once befriended.

fable1: Two neighbours came before Zeus and asked him to grant them their wishes. Now, one of them was greedy, while the other was envious. To punish them both, Zeus granted that each might have whatever he asked for, but only if his neighbour had twice as much. The greedy one prayed to have a room full of gold. No sooner said than done; but all his joy turned to grief when he saw that his companion got two rooms filled with gold. The envious man didnâ€™t want his neighbor to have any joy at all and asked for one of his own eyes to be removed, so that his companion would go completely blind.
fable2: Once upon a time, a greedy monkey incessantly stole bananas from other animals. Instead of sharing, he hoarded them all, his cavern growing full. One day, a landslide sealed the cavern entrance, trapping him inside. His only food? The rotten bananas his greed had amassed.

fable1: Some storks chose a field newly sown with wheat as their new feeding ground. The owner of the field, for a while, scared them away by waving an empty sling. Once the storks found out that the sling was empty, they started to ignore the farmerâ€™s threats. In response, the farmer charged the sling with stones, killing dozens of the birds in quick succession.
fable2: Once, in a forest, a wise old elephant pleaded with a mischievous monkey to stop stealing fruits from his tree. The monkey ignored the elephant's words, laughing and continuing his theft. Finally, the elephant, in frustration, shook the tree mightily, sending the monkey tumbling to the ground. From then on, the monkey never dared to steal from the elephant's tree.

fable1: A farmer covered his wheat field with nets in order to catch some of the storks who had been eating the freshly sown seeds. Among the storks, he also caught a robin, who broke his little leg. The robin asked the farmer to spare and release him. "Please let me go, as my broken limb is most pitiful and I am not a stork, but a robin - a good and honest bird. I love my father and mother and have a plumage quite unlike that of a stork." The farmer laughed at that, saying "This may all well be true, but I only know that I caught you together with the other thieves, and now you must perish together with them, as well."
fable2: Once there was a sparrow who desired to soar as high as an eagle. So, he left his family and friends to live among the eagles. But the eagles paid him no mind, for he was not one of them. Lonely and ignored, the sparrow returned home, realizing that his true happiness lay among his own kind.

fable1: The horse and the moose had a fight, so the horse went to the woodsman and asked him for help in getting back at the moose. The woodsman agreed, saying: "If you want my help, I will have to place this iron between your jaws to be able to guide you with these reins. I must also saddle you, so that I can keep steady as we pursue your enemy." The horse agreed and was quickly saddled and bridled. After the moose was vanquished, the horse demanded that the woodsman remove the riding equipment, to which the woodsman replied that he prefers to keep the horse just as he is.
fable2: Once, in a lush forest, lived a generous tree who gifted all his fruits to a greedy villager. The villager started selling the fruits, becoming rich and influential. With wealth and power, he craved more and convinced the tree to give him his branches and trunk too. The tree, hoping to help, agreed. However, once the villager had all he desired, he left the tree a lonely stump, useful to no one.

fable1: A magpie, dying of illness, asked her father: "Father, do not mourn my death, but instead ask the gods to save me." He replied, "Which of the gods do you think will come to your aid? Is there one among them whose altar you havenâ€™t stolen shiny offerings from?"
fable2: Once a proud peacock sat alone, basking in the grandeur of his colorful feathers. He ignored the other birds who sought his friendship, feeling he needed no one. Then winter came, stripping him of his splendid plumage and leaving him cold and lonely. The peacock sought the company of the other birds, but they had already formed their flocks. Alone, the peacock shivered.

fable1: An ape, after surviving a shipwreck, encountered a turtle who offered to carry him to the shore. To pass the time, the ape told the turtle many fantastical stories, each of them filled with lies and exaggerations.  "I see you have quite the education ", said the turtle,  "unlike me, who didnâ€™t have much schooling." As the two entered a bay, the turtle asked the ape if he knew Herring Roads, by which the bay was commonly known. The ape thought the turtle meant a famous man and, not wishing to appear ignorant, said:  "Of course I know Rhoades - he is a old college friend of mine, who also happens to be my - " The turtle couldnâ€™t bear to hear any more lies and dove quickly underwater, causing the ape to vanish forever.
fable2: Once, a mischievous fox constantly bragged about his countless victories over the lion to his fellow forest animals. One day, the lion overheard him and challenged the fox to a duel. The fox, trembling with fear, declined. The forest animals, realizing his deceit, laughed at his cowardice. From that day, the fox lived in shame and isolation, his lies having fooled no one but himself.

fable1: A raccoon and an ape were travelling together along the same road. On their way, they passed through a cemetery full of statues. "All these statues," said the ape, "are made to honor my ancestors, who achieved great things in their day." The raccoon replied, "You have picked a most appropriate subject for your lies, as it would be difficult for any of your ancestors to disagree with your words."
fable2: Once a boastful hare, known for his tall tales, claimed to outpace the wind. The animals, curious and doubtful, gathered to watch the race. When the race began, the hare sprinted as fast as he could while the wind barely stirred. But as the race progressed, the wind swiftly passed the hare before he could even realize it. The hare, panting and exhausted, couldn't meet his own claim, revealing the truth of his boastful tales.

fable1: A crab said to his daughter, "Child, why do you always walk so one-sided? It is far better to go straight forward." To which the daughter replied: "This may be so, father - why donâ€™t you show me how itâ€™s done and Iâ€™ll follow in your footsteps?" The father-crab tried and failed repeatedly, finally admitting to his daughter that he canâ€™t do it himself.
fable2: In a tree-filled forest, a young sapling asked the mighty oak how to grow tall and strong. The oak merely pointed to its own gnarled trunk and spreading branches, and said nothing. Over time, the sapling observed the oak, copying its deep roots and broad leaves. Eventually, the sapling grew into a majestic tree, understanding the silent teachings of the oak.

fable1: An angler, who was also a skilled musician, took his nets and his flute to the shore. There, he played a small concert for the fish, hoping that the music would compel them to dance into his nets that he laid below him in the water. After waiting for some time, he gave up and cast the nets into the sea, instead, catching plenty of fish in the process.
fable2: Once upon a time, a squirrel worked diligently all through autumn, stashing away food in his burrow. His neighbor, a grasshopper, laughed and spent his days in play, sparing no thought for the coming winter. Come the first snowflake, the squirrel was warm and content in his burrow, while the grasshopper was left cold and starving.

fable1: A man had a donkey and a small Pomeranian dog. The donkey lived in a stable with plenty of oats and hay, but spent his days working at the mill and carrying heavy loads of wood from the forest to the farm. The Pomeranian, on the other hand, knew many tricks and was fondled by his master, who always gave him tasty treats. The donkey envied the life of the Pomeranian and one day decided to make his way into the masterâ€™s house, imitating the Pomeranianâ€™s tricks as best as he could. In doing so, he broke the masterâ€™s table and smashed his precious dishes to pieces. Seeing this, the servants quickly drove the donkey back into the stable, kicking and beating him with clubs all the way, nearly killing him.
fable2: Once, a small sparrow admired the eagle soaring high in the sky and wished to do the same. The sparrow tried to fly higher than ever, ignoring its small wings. Unable to keep up, it fell into the sea, exhausted. Meanwhile, another sparrow gathered seeds happily, content under the clear blue sky.

fable1: A snipe had made her nest in the early spring on a recently sown wheat field. Her children have almost grown to their full size, when the owner of the field, looking over his by then ripened crop, said, "I will ask all my friends and neighbors to help me with the harvest." One of the young snipes asked his mother whether they should move to a new place for safety. "Not yet," she replied; "a man who only asks his friends to help him with the harvest does not have his mind fully set to it." A few days the farmer noticed the wheat to be heavy with grain and proclaimed: "Tomorrow, I will hire as many labourers as I can and harvest this wheat myself." Upon hearing these words, the snipe said to her children, "It is time for us to move -  a man who no longer trusts his friends, but will reap the field himself, will go through with his plans."
fable2: Once a small bird's nest was blown away by a storm. The bird pleaded with the tree, the cloud, and the wind to help retrieve its nest, but each replied they couldn't undo what nature had done. So, with courage and determination, the bird started building a new nest. After many days of hard work, it finally completed a stronger and better nest.

fable1: "Be quiet." said the nanny to the infant on her lap. "If you donâ€™t stop crying at once, I will give you to the coyote who will gobble you up." As it happened, a coyote passed by the window at just this moment. So he crouched down by the side of the house and waited until at last the infant began to cry again. Then, the coyote came forward before the window, and looked up to the nanny, wagging his tail in anticipation of his meal. But the nanny quickly shut down the window and called for help, so that the coyote ended up being chased away by dogs.
fable2: Once, a cunning fox made a promise to a trusting rabbit that he would not eat her. The rabbit, relieved, began to consider the fox a friend. However, when winter came and food was scarce, the fox ate the rabbit. As the rabbit took her last breath, she realized the naivety of her trust.

fable1: When first the raccoon encountered the tiger he was very frightened, so he ran away and hid himself in the woods. Next time, however, he came near the tiger, but stopped at a safe distance, watching the majestic beast pass him by. The third time they came near one another the raccoon went right up to the tiger, asking him how his family were, and when they may come across each other again. Once their conversation was concluded, he parted from the tiger without much ceremony or reverence.
fable2: Once, a songbird with a beautiful voice lived in a forest. The animals admired her songs and she was adored greatly. One day, a squirrel requested the songbird to live near his home, promising her the best nuts in exchange for her daily melodies. The songbird agreed and started singing near the squirrel's home every day. After a few weeks, the squirrel got used to the bird's songs and started finding them annoying. He eventually drove the songbird away, unable to bear the once-admired melody.

fable1: After being hunted down and wounded by a pack of dogs, the coyote lay sick and injured in his lair. Starving, he called to a goat who was passing by, begging him to get some water from a stream flowing nearby. "If you will bring me the water, I will be able to get myself some meat to help me recover.", the coyote said. "Yes," said the goat, "if I provide you with the water, Iâ€™m sure I will be the one providing you with the meat, as well."
fable2: Once, a cunning fox boasted loudly in the forest, claiming he'd given up his thieving ways and became a vegetarian. He preached the importance of peaceful eating habits, while his mouth was still stained red from his last meal. Even though he had a gift for eloquence, the wise old stag just smiled and walked away, refusing to be swayed.

fable1: A woodsman came into a forest, asking the trees there for a new ax handle. Agreeing to his request, the trees offered him a young birch. Having fitted the new handle, the woodsman quickly felled the largest trees in the forest. An old oak, realizing too late their mistake, commented: "Had we not given up the birch so easily, we could have continued standing here for ages."
fable2: Once a mighty lion was caught in a hunter's trap. A sly serpent, his rival, happened upon him and the lion, desperate, begged for his help. Moved by the lion's plight, the serpent fetched the key hanging nearby and freed the lion. The moment the lion was released, he pounced on the serpent, devouring him instantly.

fable1: An elderly woman who lost sight in both of her eyes called a doctor, agreeing that if he cures her blindness, he would receive a generous payment; but should his treatment fail then he would get nothing. The doctor visited the woman several times, applying a healing salve to her eyes and stealing a little of her valuables on each visit. Once he took everything of value, he healed her and asked to be paid. The woman refused, having noticed that her valuables are missing. Angered, the doctor summoned the woman before a judge, where she argued: " It is true that I promised to pay the doctor once I recover my sight. He now declares that I am healed, but I claim that I remain blind. You see, before I lost my sight, I saw in my house various valuable items: but now, although the doctor claims to have cured me, I see none of my prized possessions."
fable2: Once a jackrabbit, notorious for his mischievous pranks, decided to play a trick on the wise old tortoise. He painted a rock to look like a large, juicy carrot and left it on the tortoise's path. The tortoise, finding the rock, realized immediately that it was a trick. In response, he painted a similar rock to look like a juicy lettuce leaf and left it where the jackrabbit would find it. As anticipated, the jackrabbit chipped a tooth on the rock, proving that sometimes the prankster becomes the pranked.

fable1: A raccoon caught his tail in a trap, losing all of it but the stump in an effort to free himself. At first he was ashamed to face his kind, but then decided to embrace his fate. He summoned all the raccoons to a meeting, where he proposed that they should all remove their tails, as they were an inconvenience, making it harder to sit comfortably or run away from dogs. There was no advantage at all to having a tail, he argued.  "That is a nice speech," said one of the older raccoons; "but I doubt that you would make the same bold proposal if you still had your tail."
fable2: A young wolf, eager to prove his strength, was convinced by a cunning fox to challenge the great bear. The fox insisted the bear was a coward and would surely run away. Trusting the fox's words, the young wolf challenged the bear and was swiftly defeated. As the fox scavenged the leftovers of the defeated wolf's meal, it was clear who had truly won.

fable1: A huge tree was felled by the wind and thrown across a river. It fell among some weeds and asked them: "How are you, despite being so light and weak, not completely crushed by these strong winds?" The weeds replied, "You fight the wind, and are destroyed for that very reason; we bend before it and escape undamaged."
fable2: Once upon a time, in a dense woodland, a mighty oak tree and humble bamboo lived side by side. One stormy night, a violent wind shook the woods fiercely. The proud oak stood tall against the wind, refusing to bow, and eventually broke. The bamboo, on the other hand, bent with the wind and survived unscathed.

fable1: A coyote spotted a rabbit on the hillside and ran after her for some time. As he closed in on the rabbit, he would sometimes bite her as if intending to kill her, and playfully fawn at her at other times. Finally, the rabbit told the koyote: "I wish that you would show your true colors. Why do you bite me with such force, if you are my friend? And if you are my enemy, why do you fawn at me?
fable2: Once, a rabbit found companionship in a cunning fox. The fox, always with a smile, promised protection from predators. One day, the rabbit discovered a fox fur near his burrow and a trace of his missing sibling. His heart filled with doubt, the rabbit distanced himself from the fox, forever questioning the truth behind the fox's gleaming teeth.

fable1: One day a farmer found a huge, yellow egg next to one of his ducks that was as heavy as led. Assuming that someone was playing a trick on him, he initially wanted to throw it away. But he decided to take it home with him, after all, and soon realized that it was made of pure gold. He found a new egg every morning and soon became very rich by selling them. The richer he got, the more greedy he became, until he finally decided to get all the gold at once by killing the responsible duck. But, having killed and opened her, he found nothing inside.
fable2: Once a snake found a cave filled with gold. Blinded by the glitter, it coiled around the treasure, refusing to leave even for food. Over time, the greedy snake grew weak and starved, still wrapped around the gold it could never use.

fable1: A father, on his dying bed, wanted his children to give the same attention to his land as he himself had. Thus, he called them to his bedside and told them of a great treasure hidden in one of his vineyards. Once he had passed, his children carefully dug over every portion of their land. While they found no treasure, the vines produced a superabundant crop thanks to their labour.
fable2: In a dense forest, a beaver spent his days tirelessly building a dam. Other animals lounged lazily, teasing him for his non-stop work. One day, a flash flood hit. The animals took shelter in the beaver's strong dam. Astonished and grateful, they praised the beaver's diligence that had unknowingly saved their lives.

fable1: A drummer who led on the soldiers during their battles with his music, was captured by the enemy. He begged his captors to spare him: "I have not slain a single man of your troop. I have no arms, and carry nothing other than this one drum." "We are putting you to death for this very reason," they replied; "as it was your drum that inspired others to take up arms against us."
fable2: In a quaint forest, a mischievous monkey purposely dropped a ripe banana between an elephant and a rhino. Both large beasts claimed it as their own and soon, a ferocious fight broke out. The monkey watched from a tree, laughing at their foolishness. However, when the elephant and rhino realized they were tricked, they teamed up and chased the monkey out of the forest. The monkey learned that instigating trouble can have dire consequences.

fable1: A pilgrim about to set out on a long journey noticed his mutt standing at the door and stretching himself. Thus, he asked the mutt: "Why do you stand there doing nothing? Everything is ready but you, so come with me without any more delay." The mutt, wagging his tail, replied: "But master, I have been ready for some time and have been waiting for you."
fable2: Once, a hare and a tortoise decided to race again. The hare, confident in his speed, spent the day playing, while the tortoise steadily plodded on. As the sun began to set, the hare realized he had little time left and blamed the tortoise for setting a slow pace. Despite his complaints, it was the tortoise who crossed the finish line first.

fable1: One day, a serpent crawled out of his hole located next to the porch of an inn and bit the innkeeperâ€™s son, who soon thereafter perished. In his grief, the innkeeper decided to kill the serpent. When she next came out of her hole in search of food, the innkeeper swung at her with his ax, but only managed to cut off the end of her tail. After some time, the innkeeper became afraid that the serpent would bite him, too, and tried to make peace by offering the beast some bread and salt. Seeing this, the serpent hissed: "There can be no peace between us. Whenever you see me, you will remember the loss of your son, while I will mourn the loss of my tail whenever I see you."
fable2: Once, a snake bit a farmer who then nursed it back to health when it fell ill. The snake thanked him and promised not to bite again. Yet, each time they met, the farmer always stepped back in fear. The snake questioned this and the farmer replied, "Though you've healed, my wound still aches."

fable1: Playing near a pond, a group of children spotted some toads swimming in the water and began to pelt them with rocks. After they killed several, one of the toads lifted his head out of the water and spoke to them: "Please stop, my children: what is a game to you, is deadly to us."
fable2: In the heart of the forest, the Woodpecker loved to tap on tree trunks each morning, filling the woods with his rhythmic sound. Yet, the Hare, who lived under one of the trees, endured sleepless nights due to the persistent noise. The Woodpecker's melody was the Hare's midnight terror.

fable1: A king had some apes trained to dance, as they are by nature great mimics of human actions. They proved to be talented students and soon danced as well as the rest of the kingâ€™s court, dressed in rich clothes and masks. One day, one of the courtiers threw a handful of nuts onto the stage, as he was bent on mischief. The apes forgot their dancing at once and started to fight each other for the nuts, tearing off their robes and masks in the process. Thus, the dancing quickly came to an end, with the audience laughing and ridiculing the apes.
fable2: A proud peacock, flaunting his vibrant feathers, attracted the attention of a grumpy crow. Envious, the crow plucked his own dull feathers and replaced them with the peacock's that had fallen on the ground. When he tried to fly, the heavy, unfamiliar feathers weighed him down, causing him to fall. Meanwhile, the peacock, although less brilliant, soared high in the sky.

fable1: A young thief had been caught in the act and sentenced to death for his crimes. He asked to see his mother one last time, which was naturally granted. When his mother came to visit, he said: "I want to whisper to you," and when she came close enough, he nearly bit her ear off. All the bystanders were horrified, and asked the thief why he would do something so cruel and inhuman. "I wanted to punish her," he said. "When I was young, I stole little things and brought them home. My dear mother didnâ€™t punish or rebuke me, but laughed and said that my actions wonâ€™t be noticed by anyone. I am here today because of how she acted then."
fable2: Once a young sapling asked a grand old oak tree, "How did you grow so tall and strong?" The old oak replied, "As a seed, I fell beside a river whose gentle, nourishing waters guided my roots deep into the earth and taught me the right path to grow. Now, even as an old tree, I remain nourished and rooted in my early teachings."

fable1: A raccoon invited a stork for dinner and, for his own amusement, served nothing but soup made of pulse, which he poured into a flat stone dish. The soup fell out of the storkâ€™s long bill, and the birdâ€™s frustration was a great source of fun for the raccoon. To return the favour, the stork invited the raccoon for lunch and placed before him a jug with a long and narrow mouth - perfectly suited for the birdâ€™s bill, but useless to the raccoon who was unable to taste the jug's contents.
fable2: A hungry fox spotted a group of rabbits enjoying their meal of fresh lettuce. Instead of attacking them, he approached them gently and shared a few berries he had found earlier. The rabbits were so touched by the fox's kindness, that when winter came and food was scarce, they shared their stored food with him, ensuring they all survived the harsh season.

fable1: A bat fell to the ground where he was caught by a passing lynx. The bat begged the lynx to spare his life, but the lynx refused, saying that, by her nature, she is the enemy of all birds. As soon as he heard that, the bat assured the lynx that he was not a bird, but indeed a mouse, and thus was able to escape with his life. Some time later, the bat again fell to the ground and was caught by yet another lynx, whom he also asked to spare him. The lynx said that she is the enemy of all mice, and will therefore kill the bat. The bat, in turn, assured her that he was not a mouse, but a bird. Thus, he was able to escape once again.
fable2: In a dense forest, a small squirrel had gathered nuts for winter. One day, a fierce storm scattered all the nuts. The next morning, the squirrel woke up to find that the storm had not only scattered the nuts but also sown them around. Over time, new trees grew, providing more food than the squirrel could ever collect.

fable1: A child was stung by a nettle and ran home to tell his mother. Through tears, the child said: "Although I only touched it gently, it hurt me very much." His mother replied: "The next time you touch a nettle, grasp it as firmly as you can and it will not hurt you, but will feel soft as silk in your hand."
fable2: A young sparrow, learning to fly, was often lazy and half-hearted in her efforts. One day, while she fluttered half-heartedly, a gust of wind swept her towards a thorny bush. Panicked, she flapped with all her might, escaping the thorns unscathed. From that day on, she took flight with full force, soaring higher than all the other birds.

fable1: One day, the tiger announced that he was dying from a terrible illness and asked all animals to come and hear his last will and testament. The pig came first and remained in the tigerâ€™s cave for a long time. Next, the goat went in, followed by the cow. Both remained in the cave to receive the wishes of the mighty predator. Soon, the tiger seemed to recover and came out to the entrance of the cave, where he encountered the raccoon. "Why did you not come to pay your respects to me?", asked the tiger. The raccoon replied after bowing to the tiger: "While I saw many visitors going inside your cave, I have seen none come out. Until the animals that have visited you return into the daylight, I prefer to remain outside and enjoy the fresh air."
fable2: Once in a dense forest, a curious rabbit decided to explore the fox's den while the fox was away. Amazed by the abundance of food there, he lost track of time. Suddenly, the fox returned and blocked the den's entrance, trapping the rabbit inside. Unable to escape, the rabbit realized his mistake. No matter how much he yearned for freedom, he was now the fox's captive.

fable1: A blind woman had the unique ability to distinguish different animals just by touching them with her hands. The whelp of a coyote was brought to her, with a request that she say what it was just by holding it. She felt the animal and said: "While I do not quite know if this is a fox cub or the whelp of a coyote, it would not be wise to leave the animal alone with a flock of sheep."
fable2: Once, a young snake asked his mother, "Why do we bite if we're not hungry?" His mother replied, "That's our nature, dear." One day, the snake bit a playful puppy just passing by. The puppy's loud yelps alerted the villagers who killed the snake immediately.

fable1: A scorpion befriended an ant and the two came to trust each other greatly. One day, the ant struggled to cross a challenging and dangerous river, so the scorpion offered to take her to the other side on his back, promising not to harm her. Yet, once they crossed the river, the scorpionâ€™s tail stung the ant without warning. As she lay dying, the ant asked the scorpion why he betrayed her trust. "It is my nature.", the scorpion replied with sadness in his voice.
fable2: A rabbit, eager to fly, befriended a flock of crows and mimicked their every move. Inspired, he jumped off a cliff, flapping his ears urgently. But no matter how he wished or intended to soar, he couldn't deny his nature and fell into a soft burrow, where he realized he was made for digging, not flying.

fable1: A raccoon was climbing a hedge when he suddenly lost his footing. To break his fall, he grasped after a thistle, who pricked and torn the skin on his paws quite badly. Thus, he began to curse the thistle who hurt him more than the fall would have. The thistle, interrupting him, said, "You must have been out of your mind to hold onto me, who uses her barbs to hold onto others."
fable2: Once a greedy fox stumbled upon a vast vineyard, abundant with juicy grapes. He ate until he could eat no more, yet he decided to hoard the rest for himself. He spent his days guarding his vineyard from his fellow animals, accusing them of his own greedy intentions. But in the end, the fox was left alone, with only his precious grapes, which turned sour from his selfish touch.

fable1: A pair of hyenas, finding the skin of a tiger on the ground, began to tear it in pieces with their teeth. Seeing that, a monkey said to them: "If this tiger were still alive, you would quickly find out that his claws are much stronger and sharper than your teeth."
fable2: Once, a boastful hyena spotted a wounded lion. Seeing an opportunity, the hyena attacked, bragging about his strength to the other animals. Yet, when the lion recovered, the hyena couldn't even dare to approach him out of fear.

fable1: A jackdaw stole a piece of meat from a kitchen and, holding it in her beak, perched in a tree. A raccoon who spotted the jackdaw wanted the meat for himself and devised a clever stratagem to obtain it. "How handsome is the jackdaw," he exclaimed, "both in her shape and complexion! She should be regarded as the queen of birds if only her voice matches her appearance!" The jackdaw, anxious to live up to the flattery, opened her beak for a loud caw and dropped the meat to the ground. The raccoon promptly picked it up and said: "Your voice may be pretty, but your wit is sorely lacking, jackdaw."
fable2: Once, a humble field mouse chanced upon a snake, who praised the mouse for its sleek fur and swift speed. Taken by flattery, the mouse agreed to visit the snake's home. As soon as they entered, the snake devoured the unsuspecting mouse.

fable1: A donkey, carrying a heavy load of wood, passed through a pond. As he was crossing through the water he lost his footing, stumbled and fell. Not being able to rise due to his heavy load, he laid in the shallow water, groaning. A couple of toads living in the pond heard his cries and said to him: "What would you do if you had to live here as we do, if just falling into the water makes you cry like this?"
fable2: A painter, famed for his stunning portraits, found himself unable to create a masterpiece due to a single, incessant fly. Despite facing harsh criticisms, tight deadlines, and various hardships in his career, this small annoyance pushed him to the brink of insanity. One day, an admirer asked why this mere insect could disturb him more than the most brutal critique. The painter, swatting away the fly, simply sighed, "It's the small things that truly test our patience."

fable1: A bug went to the bank of a river to quench his thirst, but got swept away by the stream and nearly drowned. A robin was observing the events from a nearby tree and plucked a leaf of one of its branches, letting it fall into the stream close to the bug. The bug climbed onto it and floated safely to the closest bank. After some time, a birdcatcher came into the forest and was about to lay a trap under the same tree. The bug, recognizing the catcherâ€™s plan, bit him in the foot which caused the catcher to drop the trap. His pained scream, meanwhile, alerted the robin who quickly flew away.
fable2: In the forest, a tiny mouse freed a lion trapped in a hunter's net. Later, the lion found the mouse caught by a falcon. With a single roar, the lion scared the falcon away, saving the mouse.

fable1: A donkey was owned by a merchant who underfed and overworked him. Thus, the donkey petitioned Zeus for a new master to serve. After warning the donkey that he would regret this request, Zeus caused him to be sold to a brick-maker. The donkey quickly found that the loads of bricks that he now had to carry were much heavier than those of the merchant, and asked Zeus for a new master once again. The god obliged one last time and caused the donkey to be sold to a tanner, who treated him worse than either of his past owners. Thus, the donkey said, groaning: "It would have been better if I starved or died of exhaustion with one of my previous masters, since this new one will skin me after Iâ€™m dead to make me useful to him even then."
fable2: Once, a small bird named Tweety, unsatisfied with her simple nest, flew to a luxurious palace. She made her home there but complained of the noise and bustle. So, she migrated to a quiet, dark cave, but soon missed the sunlight. Next, she settled on a high tree but feared the wind. At last, Tweety returned to her original nest, realizing it wasn't the place but her attitude that needed to change.

fable1: A goat, returning from the pasture without protection, ended up being pursued by a coyote. Unable to escape, the goat turned around and said: "I know that I will be your prey, but would you play me a tune to which I may dance as one final favor before I die?" The coyote obliged and began playing his pipes. As the goat danced to the music, dogs alerted by the sound ran up and began chasing the coyote. As he ran away, the coyote commented: "I should not have turned into a piper just to please my prey, as I am a butcher by nature."
fable2: Once a trapped mouse, on the verge of becoming a cat's meal, noticed some cheese nearby. With lightning speed, he flung it far away. The greedy cat, distracted by the flying cheese, dashed after it. The mouse used this chance to escape, saving his life.

fable1: A donkey and a raccoon entered into a partnership for mutual protection and went into the forest to hunt. Soon, they came upon a tiger who noticed them right away. The raccoon, sensing imminent danger, approached the tiger and promised to help him capture the donkey if only the tiger would promise not to hurt the raccoon himself. Then, assuring the donkey that he would not be injured, the raccoon led him to a deep pit and pushed him into it without warning. Seeing that the donkey was trapped, the tiger immediately killed the raccoon, and attacked the donkey once he felt that it was time for his next meal.
fable2: Once there was a gullible rabbit who, when a sly fox promised not to eat him if he came out of his burrow, believed him. As soon as the rabbit hopped out, the fox snapped him up.

fable1: The tiger and the coyote went hunting together. On the advice of the coyote, the tiger sent a message to the donkey, proposing an alliance between their two families. Overjoyed at the prospect of a royal alliance, the donkey soon arrived at the proposed meeting place, where he quickly got pounced on by the tiger. Standing over the donkey's lifeless body, the tiger told the coyote to watch their dinner while he takes a nap. Obeying his orders, the coyote waited; but finding that his master did not return, eventually took the brains out of the donkey's head and ate them up. When the tiger returned, he noticed the absence of brains and roared at the coyote: "What have you done with the brains?" "Clearly he had none, otherwise he would never have fallen into your trap.", the coyote replied.
fable2: Once a sly fox came upon a lion trapped in a hunter's net. The lion begged for help, promising not to eat the fox. The fox chuckled, "I am not afraid of being eaten, but helping you would just mean restoring danger in the woods." The lion roared in frustration, but the fox simply trotted off, leaving the lion to his fate.

fable1: One winter a farmhand found a frozen serpent lying in the snow. Taking pity on her, he picked her up and placed her in his bosom. The serpent was quickly revived by the warmth, and bit his saviour following her natural instincts, wounding the farmhand mortally. With his last breath, the farmhand cried: "This is what I get for pitying a scoundrel!"
fable2: Once, a generous hare offered his burrow to a shivering snake in the midst of a snowstorm. The snake was warmed and welcomed but, once nourished, it bit the hare and claimed the burrow as its own.

fable1: The sparrows were terrified by the sudden appearance of a falcon and called upon the buzzard to act as their protector, who readily agreed. When they had admitted him into their flock, he ended up wrecking more havoc and slaying a greater number of sparrows than any falcon could have done.
fable2: In a bustling forest, a squirrel, eager to protect his acorns from a thieving crow, sought help from a sly fox. The fox offered to guard the acorns, promising no crow would touch them. The next day, the squirrel returned to find all his acorns gone. The fox grinned, "No crow did touch your acorns, that's for sure."

fable1: A tiger, a raccoon and a donkey agreed to help each other hunt. After having captured a large prey, the tiger asked the donkey to divide the spoils among them. The donkey carefully divided the meat into three equal parts and asked his partners to pick their share. The tiger, enraged, slayed and devoured the donkey. Next, he asked the raccoon to divide the prey. The raccoon placed almost all of the meat in a single heap, leaving for himself the smallest possible portion. Smiling, the tiger asked: "Who has taught you the art of division, my dear friend?" "I learned it from the donkey, by seeing what happened to him.", replied the raccoon.
fable2: Once, two mice lived in a barn. One day, the inquisitive mouse, ignoring the warnings, ate the cheese from a trap and got caught. The observant mouse, learning from his friend’s plight, found food elsewhere and lived a long, contented life.

fable1: A coyote noticed a sheep grazing at the edge of a steep cliff, where he would be unable to reach her. Thus, he called to her and begged her to come down, for she may slip and fall, adding that the grass was much tastier where he stood. The sheep replied, "My friend, it is not for my benefit that youâ€™re asking me to come down, but for your own, as you are clearly hungry."
fable2: Once, a fox offered to guard a rabbit's home while he went on vacation. The rabbit, delighted by the thought of a fox for a friend, accepted. Upon his return, he found his pantry empty and his house ransacked. The fox, with a full belly, merely shrugged and said, "I was just making myself comfortable."

fable1: To escape from a tiger, a farm bull decided to hide in a cave recently occupied by some shepherds. Just as soon as he entered, a familiar ram who was left in the cave attacked him with his horns. In response, the bull quietly addressed him: "I do not fear you, but I do fear the tiger. Once he is gone, I will gladly show you which one of us is stronger."
fable2: In the heart of the forest, a squirrel had lost his stash of acorns. Seeing an opportunity, a crafty fox offered him a tiny portion of his own food, but at an exorbitant price. The desperate squirrel agreed, trading his warm nest for the meagre meal. Come winter, the fox was snug in the squirrel's nest, while the squirrel shivered in the harsh cold.

fable1: After a long journey, the tired child laid down on the very brink of a deep well, overcome with exhaustion. As he was an inch away from falling into the cold water, the goddess of fortune appeared to him and woke him from his sleep. "Wake up, child", she said, "as it will be me who gets the blame should you fall into the well, since people tend to blame their troubles on me that they have brought onto themselves."
fable2: Once, a squirrel and a rabbit both found an acorn tree. The squirrel worked tirelessly, gathering acorns for the winter, while the rabbit merely frolicked, claiming the tree would provide when the time came. Winter arrived, the tree bare, leaving the squirrel well-fed and the rabbit with nothing but regret.

fable1: An antelope pursued by hunters was forced to hide in a cave known to belong to a tiger. Once she had entered the cave, the tiger pounced from the shadows and bit her neck. The antelope, with her dying breath, proclaimed:"Just my luck, to escape from man, only to fall victim to a wild beast."
fable2: Once, a small rabbit, terrified of the owl's shadow, dashed into a thicket to hide. In her panic, she didn't notice it was a thorny bush, and her fur became entangled in the sharp spines. Her struggles only pulled her further into a painful predicament.

fable1: A fly bit the head of a bald man, who slapped himself on the head in an effort to kill the offending insect. The fly, however, escaped and addressed the man: "In trying to destroy me for a tiny prick, you only added insult to injury". To this, the man replied: "I can make my peace with this, as I did not intend to hurt myself. But I wish I could have killed you, foul insect, even if that had caused me a greater injury."
fable2: Once, a scorpion stung a young elephant out of spite. The little elephant, filled with rage, pursued the scorpion relentlessly. Eventually, he caught up to the scorpion and squashed it with his foot. However, as he walked away victorious, he felt a sharp pain; the scorpion's sting was still in his foot, causing an infection that took a long time to heal.

fable1: A jackdaw saw a majestic swan and wanted to have the same, beautiful plumage. Assuming that the swanâ€™s feathers got their brilliant color from being washed in the lake in which he swam, the jackdaw left behind the neighborhoods where she scavenged for a living, and moved to a pond. But, despite washing her feathers repeatedly in the water, they remained black, and as she couldnâ€™t find food in the new surroundings, the jackdaw soon perished.
fable2: Once, a mighty and fierce lion decided to become a vegetarian, tired of his brutal reputation. He consumed only grass and fruit, impressing the entire jungle with his transformation. However, one day, a juicy gazelle wandered near him. Unable to suppress his inherent instincts, he pounced and devoured it in an instant, his old habits roaring back to life.

fable1: A puddle of honey, spilled from an overturned jar in a kitchen, attracted a group of flies. They ate the honey greedily, landing on the puddle with their feet. Thus, they became stuck, unable to lift themselves out of the puddle with the help of their wings, and soon suffocated. As they perished, they cried: "What fools we are, having sacrificed ourselves for a small pleasure."
fable2: A bee, desiring the sweetness of a flower, thrust itself deep into its heart. In its fervor, it ignored the impending danger, and was soon trapped in the sticky pollen. It writhed in angst, its wings coated with the sweetness it so desired. Its joy turned bitter as it realized freedom was an impossible dream.

fable1: According to an old legend, the lark was created even before the Earth itself. When her father died, she could not bury him, as there was no ground to dig a grave in. After five days, still not having buried his body, the lark buried him in her own head not knowing what else to do. It is said that the crest on the larkâ€™s head is, therefore, her fatherâ€™s gravestone.
fable2: In a lush green forest, a young, impulsive deer often disregarded his mother's advice, believing his swift legs would protect him from all perils. One day, ignoring her warnings again, he wandered away and fell into a trap. His mother, knowing the forest well, found and freed him. From that day, the young deer never defied his mother’s guidance, understanding her wisdom was his truest shield.

fable1: While fleeing from a pack of dogs, the raccoon came across a woodsman felling a tree and begged him for a safe hiding place. The woodsman offered him his hut, so the raccoon quickly ran inside and hid in a corner. A hunter with his dogs soon arrived at the scene and asked the woodsman whether he had seen a raccoon run by. The woodsman replied that he had not, but kept pointing at the hut as he spoke. The hunter, however, remained oblivious to his signs, and continued with his chase past the hut. Once the air had cleared, the raccoon left the hut and was about to depart, when the woodsman reprimanded him: "How ungrateful of you to leave without a word of thanks, even though I saved your life." To that, the raccoon replied: "I would have thanked you if your actions had been as good as your words, and your speech had not been betrayed by your hands."
fable2: A clever fox, known for his slyness, found a group of birds with a golden egg. He winked at his friend, the hyena, and whispered, "I'll distract them, you grab the egg." However, the eagle, sharp-eyed as ever, caught the fox's wink and alerted all. They flew away with the egg, leaving the fox and hyena in utter dismay.

fable1: On his way home after a successful hunt, the hunter ran into a fisherman who carried a bucket full of fish. As the hunter fancied some of the fish and the fisherman wanted some of the hunterâ€™s meat, the two agreed to an equitable exchange. Both were pleased and repeated the same exchange day after day. A neighbor, who spotted them trading their goods commented: "If you keep doing this every day, you will soon lose any enjoyment of the exchange as it will become the norm, and instead will desire to keep your own bounty."
fable2: Once, in a lush forest, two squirrels spent the whole summer collecting nuts and berries. One squirrel ate all his treats immediately, while the other squirrel saved his for the winter. When winter came, the first squirrel shivered with hunger, but the second squirrel sat warm and satisfied in his nest, eating his stored food.

fable1: A deer lost sight in one of his eyes and could not see anything on the affected side. Thus, to avoid danger, he always fed on a high cliff overlooking the sea, with his remaining eye pointed towards the land, which allowed him to spot any approaching hunters and escape. But, some hunters eventually found out about his partial blindeness and decided to hire a boat, shooting the deer from under the cliff that he was feeding on.
fable2: Once, a hare heard from a crow that he would be eaten by a fox. Frightened, the hare left the meadow and hid in a cave, only to be cornered by a hungry fox seeking shelter from the rain.

fable1: A raccoon was sneaking around a hen-coop one night, when he noticed a rooster sitting on the coopâ€™s roof. "Good news, friend rooster!", said the raccoon, "King lion has proclaimed a truce among all animals. From now on, no animal may hurt another, and we all shall live in brotherly friendship.". The rooster replied: "That is good news, indeed! But wait, I can see someone coming with whom we can share such good news." and craned his neck to better recognize the new arrival. "Who is it?", asked the raccoon. "Itâ€™s only my masterâ€™s dog and heâ€™s coming to join us. Oh, are you leaving so soon?", he continued, noticing that the raccoon began to back away from the coop in a hurry. "Will you not embrace the dog as your friend and brother?" To this, the raccoon replied, before running away: "Iâ€™d love to, but Iâ€™m afraid he might not have heard of the lionâ€™s decree yet."
fable2: A crafty fox, known for its tricks, decided to play a prank on a group of chickens. He planted a scarecrow, hoping they would run into his den out of fear. However, the chickens, mistaking the scarecrow for a farmer, didn’t dare to leave their coop. The fox, frustrated and hungry, went to remove the scarecrow and accidentally scared the chickens into his den, but in the chaos, he tripped over the scarecrow, allowing the chickens to escape and leaving the fox hungry and embarrassed.

fable1: The crow has always been jealous of the raven, as he was considered to be a bird of good omen and was valued by men who tried to predict future events from the patterns of his flight. Hoping to become a bird of importance herself, the crow flew up into a tree and waited for travelers to approach. Once a group arrived at the tree, the crow cawed as loudly as she could, attracting the travellersâ€™ attention. However, one of them soon turned to his companions and said: "Let us continue with our journey, as this is just a useless crow. Her cry is no omen and best to be ignored."
fable2: Once, a sparrow admired the elegant and graceful swans so much that it painted itself white and tried to swim in the lake. The swans, seeing the sparrow's clumsy attempts, laughed heartily. Meanwhile, the sparrows on the shore wondered why their friend was acting so strangely and began to laugh as well.

fable1: Two men were travelling together. One of them spotted an ax lying in the grass off the path and said to his companion: "I found an ax!" His companion replied: "No, my friend, we have found an ax." Not much later, they noticed that the owner of the ax was pursuing them. Realizing their predicament, the man who found the ax said: "We are in trouble!", to which his companion replied: "No, my friend, you are in trouble."
fable2: Two mice stumbled upon a large chunk of cheese in a perilous mousetrap. Despite the risks, they decided to work together to retrieve it. One mouse distracted the cat, while the other swiftly took the cheese. When they were safe, the mouse who took the cheese refused to share, claiming he did all the work. That night, the cat caught him, attracted by the smell of the cheese. The other mouse, having nothing to attract the cat, remained safe.

fable1: A pair of travellers encountered a bear during their journey. One of them, upon seeing the animal, quickly climbed up the nearest tree and hid in the branches. The other, seeing that he was the only one left for the bear to attack, slumped to the ground and pretended as best as he could to be dead. The bear soon left him be, as bears are known to ignore lifeless bodies. Once the bear was well out of sight, the first traveler descended from the tree and jokingly asked his companion if the bear told him anything useful. "He really did.", replied his companion, "He told me not to travel with someone who deserts you at the first sign of danger."
fable2: Once a wealthy mouse, full of friends, lost all his cheese in a fire. Overnight, his friends disappeared, all except for one, a small field mouse. This loyal friend shared his grain and never left his side, proving that true friendship shines brightest in the darkest hours.

fable1: A gazelle came to a spring to quench her thirst. Noticing her reflection in the water, she admired the length of her horns, but was very disappointed by how slender and weak her legs seemed to be. As she was contemplating her appearance, a tiger snuck up on her and was about to pounce, when the gazelle at last noticed him and took flight. She was easily able to outrun the tiger on an open plane due to the strength of her legs, but her horns got caught in tree branches as soon as she entered a forest. This allowed the tiger to catch up and devour her.
fable2: In a bustling forest, a shiny gold coin lay next to a simple acorn. The animals ignored the acorn, mesmerized by the gold's sparkle. They fought over the coin, while a tiny squirrel quietly picked up the acorn and planted it. Many seasons passed, and the coin lay forgotten, but the acorn grew into a magnificent, life-giving tree.

fable1: On an especially hot and sunny afternoon, two travellers sought respite in the shadow cast by a palm tree. As they enjoyed the cool shade, one of them commented:"What a useless tree is the palm - it bears no fruit and is otherwise of no use to people." Upon hearing this, the palm interrupted the traveler: "How ungrateful people are! How dare you call me useless while escaping from the sun in my shade?"
fable2: Once a fisherman stumbled upon a magical fish who offered him one wish. He wished for unending wealth and lived lavishly, but soon became lonely as people only sought his riches. One day, he realized his old simple life with love and companionship was the true treasure he had overlooked.

fable1: It is known that some older women sometimes enjoy a glass of wine. One such woman spotted a wine-jar lying by the side of the road and went up to it, hoping that it still had its contents. Sadly, the jar was empty. Yet, the woman still took a long sniff at the mouth of the jar, enjoying the lingering smell.
fable2: A young boy named Tom received a beautiful guitar for his birthday. He played it day and night, creating melodies that filled his home with joy. Years passed and Tom became a famous musician. One day, he found a newer, grander guitar but he couldn’t let go of his old one. He realized the old guitar carried the melodies of his past and the echoes of his happiness.

fable1: One day, a snake found his way into a forge. As she slithered across the floor, she felt her skin irritated by a file that had fallen to the ground. Hurt and enraged, the snake turned to the file, exposed her fangs, and tried to bite it. However, none of her efforts had any effect on the heavy iron file.
fable2: Once a rock sat in the path of an ambitious ant. The ant, determined to remove the obstacle, bit and clawed at the stone all day. Yet, the rock remained unmoved and indifferent. Exhausted and broken, the ant finally realized that some obstacles are better left alone.

fable1: A coyote, who was used to eating eggs, came across an oyster on his walk across the beach. Taking it to be a strange-looking egg, he opened his jaws as far as he could and swallowed it whole. Soon enough, his stomach started to hurt badly, causing him to regret having acted on uninformed assumptions.
fable2: In the heart of the jungle, a young, adventurous monkey discovered a shiny object high up in a tree. Overwhelmed by curiosity and oblivious to the gusty wind, he leapt towards it without a moment's pause. Mid-jump, a sudden gust blew him off course, causing him to crash into a thorny bush instead of landing on the tree, and the shiny object turned out to be a mundane leaf glinting in the sun.

fable1: Zeus and Aphrodite were at odds as to whether it is possible for a living being to change its nature. To settle their argument, the deities turned a cat into a woman and arranged for a man to fall in love with her and for them to marry. The ceremony went well, prompting Zeus to say: "See how well she is behaving! Nobody suspects that she used to be a cat. Her nature must have changed." Aphrodite asked him to wait and let loose a mouse inside the wedding hall. Once the bride saw the mouse, she jumped up from her seat and ran after the mouse on all fours in an attempt to catch her.
fable2: In a bustling city, a lonely, tiny seed fell into a crack in the concrete. Ignored by all, it endured harsh conditions and scarcity of nutrients. Yet, with tenacity, it pushed through the concrete, transforming into a beautiful flower. It flourished amidst the grey cityscape, admired by everyone for its resilience and beauty.

fable1: There once was a slave who escaped his master and ran into the forest to hide from pursuers. There, he came across a tiger, who was lying on the ground, groaning with pain. At first, the slave tried to run away in fear, but soon noticed that the tiger did not chase after him and carefully approached the animal. Noticing the human, the tiger put out a swollen and bloody paw, with a huge thorn stuck in its middle. Seeing this, the slave pulled out the thorn and bandaged up the wound as best he could, thus befriending the tiger who followed him like a friendly dog. The tiger brought the man to his cave and shared his meals with him to show his gratitude. However, after a short while, the two were captured by the manâ€™s former master. As a punishment for his escape, the slave was sentenced to be thrown to the tiger, who was kept without food until that time. The emperor decided to observe the execution. Soon, the slave was led into the middle of an arena, and the tiger was let loose from his cage. But the animal instantly recognized his human companion and licked his hands with devoted affection. This surprised the emperor, who summoned the slave and asked him to tell the story of how he tamed the tiger. Having heard the tale, the emperor freed the slave and released the tiger back into his native forest.
fable2: Once a humble bee, saved from a web by a mighty lion, promised to repay the kindness. One day, the lion was threatened by a hunter's snare. The bee, remembering the lion's kindness, stung the hunter, causing a commotion that freed the lion. The lion roared out his thanks, proving that even the king of beasts knows the value of a small friend's gratitude.

fable1: A coyote with a bone stuck in his throat promised a crane a handsome payment if she could put her head inside his mouth and extract the bone. The crane obliged and, having removed the obstruction, asked for her deserved compensation. Grinning, the coyote replied: "Surely the fact that you were able to safely remove your head from between my jaws is payment enough."
fable2: Once, a naive rabbit helped a venomous snake, who had fallen into a pit. Grateful, the snake promised not to harm the rabbit. However, as the rabbit turned to leave, the snake bit him. "But you promised!" gasped the rabbit. "Ah, but I am a snake," it hissed, "it's in my nature to bite."

fable1: Three animal families inhabited an old oak - a buzzard made her nest at the top, a lynx and her kittens found a convenient hole in the middle of its trunk, and a boar with her children found shelter in its roots. The lynx, however, decided to destroy this accidental neighborhood. To this end, she spoke to the buzzard: "We are both in great danger! The boar plans to uproot the tree and feast on both of our families.". Next, the lynx spoke to the boar: "I overheard the buzzard planning to pounce upon your little piglets the next time youâ€™re away foraging for food." Having thus terrified both of her neighbors, the lynx hid in her hollow, only sneaking out during the night to procure food for herself and her family. At the same time, neither the buzzard nor the boar dared to leave their homes, being weary and scared of each other. Thus, they both soon perished of hunger, as did their families, and the lynx devoured their remains.
fable2: Once, a swift hare overheard a gossiping crow, who claimed a lion had moved into their forest. Fearing for his life, the hare spread the news and created panic among the animals. However, when they confronted the crow, it simply shrugged, admitting it had only made a wild guess. The forest was filled with unnecessary fear due to unfounded chatter.

fable1: Coming out of a field of oats, a coyote spotted a horse grazing nearby. Approaching the horse, he said: "This field is full of delicious oats that I have left untouched for your benefit, as you are my friend and it would make me happy if you had a nice meal. You should go and taste them." The horse replied: "I doubt that you would have been as generous, if oats were a popular food among coyotes."
fable2: In a dense forest lived a notorious snake, feared by all due to his venomous bite. One day, a rabbit got trapped in a hunter's net. Noticing this, the snake decided to help for once and bit through the net, setting the rabbit free. However, when the rabbit returned home, he warned everyone about the snake's dangerous fangs, but never mentioned his benevolent act.

fable1: On a hot summer day, the tiger fell asleep in his cave. As he was lying on the ground, a mouse ran across his back and face, waking him from his slumber. Enraged, the tiger began searching for the mouse in every corner of his cave, but found nothing. Observing the spectacle, a raccoon remarked: "How odd to see a tiger this scared of a mouse." "I do not fear the mouse", replied the tiger, "I resent his familiarity and lack of manners."
fable2: In a bustling hive, a young bee decided one day to sneak a little extra honey for himself, thinking it harmless. Over time, his small indulgence grew into a habit, causing a slow but steady decrease in the hive's stock. As winter approached, the hive found itself lacking in honey, leading to a harsh season of scarcity.

fable1: Having not eaten for days, a gaunt wolf came across a house-dog as he approached a village. "Ah, cousin - I always knew your wild life would be the end of you", said the dog. "Why donâ€™t you live a life like mine, where food is regularly given to you in exchange for honest work? I can easily arrange this for you." "I would like that!", replied the wolf. Thus, the wolf followed the dog into the village. As they walked side by side, the wolf noticed a bald patch on the dogâ€™s neck, where the fur seemed to have been worn away, so he asked his companion how it came to be this way. "Itâ€™s nothing", replied the dog, "This is just the spot where the collar rubs against my neck when Iâ€™m chained up at night. Itâ€™s not that bad once you get used to it." "If that is all,", said the wolf, "then I would rather return to the forest."
fable2: Once, a proud eagle was offered a deal by a cunning snake. "Join me, and you will never hunger," hissed the snake, promising daily meals if the eagle would only forsake the sky. The eagle, seeing the snake's obese, chained pet mouse, declined, choosing the uncertainty of the hunt over guaranteed captivity.

fable1: Two pots were carried downstream by a river, one made of clay and the other made of brass. The clay pot said to the brass one: "Please stay far away from me, as I will break into pieces if we collide. I will do my best to avoid you, as well."
fable2: Once, a lion and a mouse decided to become friends. The lion, confident in his power, constantly disregarded the mouse's opinions and belittled him. One day, the lion found himself trapped in a hunter's net. The mouse, taking the opportunity to prove his worth, gnawed through the net, freeing the lion. The humbled lion realized then that power did not define the value of a friend, and treated the mouse as his equal henceforth.

fable1: In his search for food, the grasshopper came across a chrysalis that was very near its time of change. The chrysalis moved its tail attracting the grasshopperâ€™s attention, who initially didnâ€™t think that it was a living being. "What a sad life you live, strange creature", remarked the grasshopper, "While I can jump around at my leisure, you are trapped within your shell and unable to move more than your scaly tail." The chrysalis heard the unpleasant comments but did not reply. A couple of days later, the grasshopper came by the chrysalis again, but only found an empty shell. Wondering what happened, he suddenly felt himself shaded and fanned by the beautiful wings of a gorgeous butterfly. "It is I, your much-pitied friend!", said the butterfly to the grasshopper, "Please boast again of your superiority, but only as long as you can reach me." Having said that, the butterfly rose to the sky and was soon invisible to the grasshopper.
fable2: Once, a tiny mouse, intrigued by the sweet aroma, found a shiny piece of cheese. Nearby, a large cat watched, his fur glistening and eyes warm, appearing as a gentle giant. The mouse, trusting the cat's friendly appearance, went to share his cheese. But as the mouse approached, the cat revealed his true nature, snapping forward in a swift attempt to catch the mouse. Luckily, the mouse escaped, leaving the cheese behind.

fable1: A masterful archer decided to hunt in the mountains, but every animal that he encountered fled at his approach. Only the tiger stood his ground. The archer immediately shot an arrow at the tiger, saying: "Iâ€™m only sending you a messenger. But he will let you know what to expect when I attack you personally." The wounded tiger fled fearing for his life and hid in his cave. A raccoon who happened to see the whole spectacle unfold, told the tiger that he shouldnâ€™t have backed off after the very first attack. But the tiger replied: "Your words mean nothing to me. How can I possibly fight someone who sends such a terrifying message?"
fable2: Once upon a time, a brave rabbit was bragging to a wise owl about his speed. "No predator can ever catch me!" he boasted. "Even the sly fox can't touch me!" The owl simply nodded and pointed to a hunter far off in the distance. Before the rabbit could understand, an arrow whizzed through the air, narrowly missing him. The rabbit scampered away, his pride stung by the near miss.

fable1: One day, a donkey found a tigerâ€™s skin left behind by a group of hunters to dry in the sun. The donkey decided to put the skin on and head to the nearest village. Animals and humans alike fled as he approached, which filled him with such pride that he began to bray. Once everyone realized that this tiger was, in fact, a donkey, his owner gave him a solid beating for the terror he caused the villagers.
fable2: Once upon a time, a crow found a lush velvet cloak and a jeweled crown discarded by a king. He dressed himself up, gaining admiration from all the other birds. One day, he was asked to address his admirers. However, as he opened his beak, out came only caws and squawks, and the birds all laughed, realizing he was not a king, but just a crow in a fancy disguise.

fable1: It is said that a monkey has two kids at each birth. One is fondled and nurtured by his mother, receiving the greatest affection, while the other is hated and neglected. Once, it happened that the favourite child was smothered by the overpowering love of his parent, while the hated child prospered in spite of the neglect that he experienced.
fable2: Once a hardworking ant, eager to prepare for winter, picked the largest grain of wheat he could find. With immense effort, he tried to carry it back to his colony. However, despite his determination and good intentions, the grain was too heavy and he tumbled down a hill. The ant was safe but the grain was lost in the river. Therefore, he returned to his colony empty-handed.

fable1: Desiring to have a ruler, the toads send ambassadors to Zeus, asking him to grant their wish. Thus, Zeus placed a log into the toadsâ€™ pond, assuming that it would suffice for such simple creatures. Initially terrified of the log, the toads soon realized that it remained motionless and posed no danger. Seeing the log as unfit to be their ruler, the toads petitioned Zeus once more. Thus, he sent an eel to govern them. As the eel was good-natured and made no demands of the toads, they felt misunderstood by the deity and once again asked him to provide them with a proper ruler. Annoyed, Zeus sent a heron to live in their pond, who soon ate all of the toads.
fable2: Once, a content little bird lived in a snug nest atop a sturdy tree. One day, she noticed a taller tree nearby. Thinking her home would be grander up higher, she laboriously moved every twig and straw. After days of toil, she finally settled in. However, the high winds shook her new home violently, making her unable to rest. Longing for her previous stable home, she realized it had been claimed by another bird.

fable1: A birch tree boasted to a shrub, "My wood is valuable and is used everywhere in roofs and walls of houses, while you have no use whatsoever." The shrub replied: "Had you considered the axes and saws that are used to harvest your wood, I think you'll end up wishing to be a useless shrub like me."
fable2: Once, a humble farmer and a wealthy merchant lived in the same village. The merchant, though rich, was always worried about bandits, market fluctuation, and his own greed. The farmer, though poor, slept peacefully after a day's toil, content with his simple life. One day, the merchant, tired of his constant worries, traded his wealth for the farmer's peace and simplicity.

fable1: A toad left his home in the marsh and moved to the forest, where he introduced himself to the animals as a skilled doctor able to heal any disease. Doubting such bold proclamations, the raccoon asked: "How can you claim to be such an excellent doctor if youâ€™re unable to heal your own wrinkled skin and lame gait?"
fable2: In a bustling town, a renowned doctor was famous for curing all kinds of ailments. Yet, he himself was always pale and sickly. One day, a young patient asked, "Why don't you cure yourself, Doctor?" The doctor just smiled weakly, realizing he'd spent so much time healing others, he'd forgotten to take care of himself.

fable1: In an attempt to escape a pack of pursuing dogs, a stag fled inside a stable and hid himself in a pile of hay, with only the tips of his horns visible to the outside. Soon, the stable was visited by hunters trailing their dogs. They asked the stable boys, who were resting after their dinner, if they had seen a stag, but looking around the stable, neither were able to spot the stag. After some time, the master of the stable came in and, pointing at the pile of hay, asked what the two strange things sticking out of it were. When the stable boys examined the pile, they quickly discovered the stag and killed him.
fable2: In a bustling marketplace, a cunning thief decided to steal fruits from a blind fruit vendor. He assumed the vendor couldn't notice his actions due to his lack of sight. However, the vendor, sensing the weight of his cart lighten, immediately recognized the thief's deception and called for the guards. The thief was caught and learned that even without sight, the vendor was more alert than he had assumed.

fable1: Lying on his deathbed, an old man summoned his children to give them one last piece of advice. He asked his servant to collect a bundle of sticks and give it to his eldest son. "Try to break it.", the old man said. The son tried his best, but was unable to break the bundle. Neither could any of the other children. Seeing this, the man asked them to untie the sticks and each take and break a single stick, which was easily accomplished. "This is my final lesson for you.", said the man.
fable2: Once, in a dense forest, a group of birds were captured in a hunter's net. Frantically, they fluttered and flapped, each trying to escape on its own, but the net held tight. Suddenly, the smallest bird chirped a tune, encouraging all the birds to flap together. As they did so, their combined force lifted the net, carrying them all to freedom.

fable1: A thief tried to break into a house during the night and brought with him some sausages to appease the house dog and keep him from barking. As the thief threw the sausages towards the dog, he addressed the intruder as follows: "Do not think that those will stop me from raising my voice. I am now even more weary of you, as your kind gesture likely serves your own goals which will, ultimately, cause trouble for me and my master."
fable2: Once upon a time, a sly fox offered a juicy chicken to a wary guard dog to gain entry into the henhouse. The dog, enticed by the delicious offering, allowed the fox inside. By sunrise, not a single hen was left untouched.

fable1: A man agreed to buy a donkey from his owner under the condition that he could try the animal out first. Thus, he brought the donkey to his home and put him in the stable together with his other donkeys. The new arrival ignored most of his new brethren, quickly joining the most idle of them who was also the greatest eater. Witnessing this, the man quickly took the donkey back to his owner and withdrew his offer. This surprised the owner who asked how the man could decide this so quickly. "I know that the donkey will not be different from the one he chose to befriend in my stable.", replied the man.
fable2: In the heart of the forest, a dove befriended a group of crows. One day, a hunter came and aimed his arrow at the crows, mistaking the dove as one of them. The dove, caught in the confusion, found itself ensnared in the hunter's trap.

fable1: In a garden, a rose grew next to an amaranth. One day, the amaranth said to her neighbor: "Your beauty and sweet scent are to be envied! Iâ€™m not surprised that you are beloved by all.". The rose replied, with sadness in her voice: "My friend, my bloom only lasts for a short while. Eventually, my petals will wither and I will perish. You, on the other hand, are everlasting, as your flowers do not fade even when cut."
fable2: Once, a mighty oak stood tall and proud, visible from miles away. It was admired for its strength, grandeur, and age. One day, a terrible storm rolled in. The smaller trees, humble and flexible, bent with the wind and survived unscathed. But the mighty oak, too proud and rigid, was struck by lightning and split in two.

fable1: In his attempt to cross a rapid river, the raccoon was swept away by the strong current and carried into a deep ravine, where he remained unable to move due to his injuries. A swarm of blood-sucking flies soon found him and descended onto his skin. Some time later, the raccoon was discovered by a sparrow, who asked if she should scare away the flies that were tormenting him. Weakly, the raccoon replied: "Please do not disturb them. The flies that you see have drunk plenty of my blood and no longer sting me much. If you scare them away, new flies will arrive who are hungry and will suck me dry."
fable2: In the heart of the forest, two squirrels, one affluent and one impoverished, each stole an acorn from a sleeping bear. The wealthy squirrel was content, but the needy one, driven by desperation, returned for more. The bear awoke, angry and hungry, and chased the poor squirrel away with nothing.

fable1: A hawk was tracking a rabbit while perching on a tree branch, preparing to swoop down and catch her. At the same time, a bowman hidden in the bushes released an arrow at the hawk, piercing his heart. As he was dying, the hawk noticed that the feathers adorning the arrow were his own and lamented: "How tragic that I must die of an arrow that would not exist without my help."
fable2: There once was a mighty lion who found a broken, skinny snake in his territory. The lion, priding himself on his generous heart, nursed the snake back to strength. One day, the snake fully recovered, bit the lion fatally. The lion, in his last moments, bitterly regretted his misplaced kindness.

fable1: A coyote spent a great deal of time trying to snatch one of the sheep away from the flock, but kept failing due to the watchful shepherd and his dogs. One day, he found a sheepskin that was left in the sun to dry and threw it over his own pelt, allowing him to walk among the sheep undetected. Eventually, a lamb recognized the skin as belonging to her mother and started to follow the coyote, who led her apart from the flock and ate her.
fable2: Once, a mouse saw a picture of a cat in a magazine. Drawn by its fluffy fur and gentle eyes, the mouse declared, "Such a lovely creature can't be as dangerous as they say." It wasn't until he met a real cat, claws extended, that he understood pictures don't show the whole truth.

fable1: In an unlikely turn of events, a raccoon befriended a hawk and both decided to live in the same tree. The hawk built a nest in its upper branches, while the raccoon found a home in the underwood and started a family. Not long after, the raccoon left to procure food for her children, which the hawk took as an opportunity to do the same and seized one of the kits to feed to her own brood. Upon returning, the raccoon was saddened to find one of her children missing but was even more aggrieved that she couldnâ€™t avenge its death. The hawk, however, soon received an appropriate punishment. One day, she spotted villagers sacrificing a sheep on an altar and swooped down to steal some of the meat, carrying it back to her nest along with a burning cinder. The cinder grew into a flame fanned by the strong winds at the top of the tree, setting the nest on fire and burning the fledglings to a crisp. As they fell to the ground, the raccoon ate them up in clear view of the hawk.
fable2: Once, a hungry fox found a basket of fruits by the river but couldn't reach it. A rabbit nearby saw the fox's struggle and helped him get the basket. Later, the fox spotted a hunter aiming at the rabbit and swiftly knocked the hunter's arrow off course, saving the rabbit's life.

fable1: The hares were engaged in a one-sided war with the wolves and asked the raccoons for their help. An emissary of the raccoons replied: "We would have loved to help you, if only we didnâ€™t know who you are and who your enemy is."
fable2: One day, a moth saw a flame and fell in love. The moth dreamed of embracing the flame's warmth and beauty and, without hesitation, it flew towards it. The moth's friends warned of the danger, but it was too entranced with the flame's allure. Without considering the consequences, the moth threw itself into the flame, only to extinguish its own life.
