fable1: By accident, a raccoon fell into a deep well without any way to get out again. Soon, a sheep came to the same well, intending to quench her thrust. There, she saw the raccoon and asked whether the water was good to drink. The raccoon praised the water as being of highest quality and encouraged the sheep to come down and try for herself, which she quickly did. Once she was equally stuck at the bottom of the well, the raccoon proposed a way for them to escape together: "If you stand against the wall on your hind legs, I will run up your back and escape. Afterwards I will help you out, too." The sheep agreed and allowed the raccoon to climb on top of her, who was thus able to reach the mouth of the well. Once outside, he started running away as fast as he could, leaving the sheep behind. As the sheep cursed at him for breaking his promise, the raccoon retorted: "You fool, had you thought first, you would have never gotten yourself into a situation from which you could not escape, nor enabled me to take a path to freedom that you could not follow."
fable2: In the forest, a young rabbit, eager to prove his bravery, decided to cross the roaring river without inspecting the stepping stones. As he hopped onto the first stone, he was swept away by the current because the stone was loose. The older, wiser rabbit on the bank sighed, watching the young rabbit flail in the water before swimming to safety.

fable1: A boy came across a pitcher filled with candy and, wanting to have some for himself, stuck his hand inside it. He grasped as much candy as he could in his fist, but found himself unable to get his hand out again, as his fist would not fit through the narrow neck of the pitcher. This caused him to break out in tears of frustration and disappointment. A passerby noticed the crying child and advised him to take out less candy, since that would allow him to relax his fist and draw out his hand more easily.
fable2: In a bustling forest, a hyperactive squirrel decided to gather nuts for the entire winter in a single day. With cheeks stuffed and paws grasping, he scurried tirelessly, barely avoiding the predatory hawk overhead and the snake below. That night, exhausted and panting, he found half his collection lost, and the other half spoiled from being dragged along the forest floor. The squirrel learned that haste made waste, and that sometimes, less is indeed more.

fable1: A war between birds and beasts was about to break out, and the bat was unsure which side she should join. The birds asked her to help them, to which the bat replied: "Iâ€™m a beast.". Later, beasts passed by underneath her nest and offered her to join them, instead. "Iâ€™m a bird.", the bat insisted. Before things could get worse, diplomacy prevailed and a conflict was avoided. To celebrate the truce, the bat tried to join the festivities of the birds, who quickly turned against her. She then attempted to join the beasts' celebrations, but they, too, drove her away.
fable2: Once upon a time, a chameleon named Charlie prided himself on his ability to change colors and blend in with any crowd. One day, he joined a gathering of zebras and turned black and white. The next day, he mingled with parrots, donning their vibrant hues. But when danger approached, the zebras and parrots fled, not recognizing Charlie as one of their own. Alone and vulnerable, Charlie realized that his ever-changing identity had left him without a place among true friends.

fable1: At a country fair, one of the performers amused the townsfolk by mimicking the cries of various farm animals. To finish his act, he squeaked very much like a pig would, making the audience wonder if he really had a piglet on stage. One of the spectators, however, was unimpressed. "You call that a pigâ€™s squeak? It sounds nothing like that! Come back here tomorrow and Iâ€™ll prove you wrong." The next day, the man went up the stage as promised, and squeaked so terribly that the audience booed and threw stones at him in protest. Protecting himself, the man exclaimed: "You fools, look at what youâ€™re booing!" and revealed a little piglet whose ear he had been pinching to produce the squeals.
fable2: In a dense forest, a mockingbird was known for perfectly imitating the voices of other birds. One day, he mimicked the song of the nightingale, who was considered the finest singer in the woods. The other animals were overjoyed, applauding and praising the mockingbird for his beautiful music. The following day, when the real nightingale sang her song, the animals complained, criticizing her for copying the mockingbird's melody.

fable1: An elderly lion was rapidly approaching his end and laid down in his cave, struggling to breath. Seeing him in such a dire shape, other animals approached him, drawing closer the weaker he got. Having made sure that he would not be able to defend himself, the animals decided to pay him back for all the grievances he caused them throughout his life. Thus, the boar tore into his body with her tusks and the bull impaled him on his horns. Lastly, even the donkey, feeling himself safe from any retribution, turned his tail to the lion and kicked him in the face.
fable2: Once in the jungle, a feeble lion, the once formidable king, lay on his deathbed. An insolent hyena, seeking to seize power, began to mock and jeer at the lion's impending demise. The other animals, watching in silence, swiftly turned their backs on the hyena, their respect for their dying king overshadowing their fear of the future.

fable1: A knight, wearing a wig to conceal his baldness, went hunting. As he approached the forest, a sudden gust of wind swept the wig from his head, causing laughter to ring out from his companions. The knight himself started to laugh, as well, joking that it is no surprise that the hairpiece would abandon him, since it wouldnâ€™t even stay on the head of the man who grew it in the first place.
fable2: Once a proud peacock stood atop a hill, boasting about his colorful feathers to all the animals. One day, a humble sparrow suggested he should thank the heavens for his beauty. The peacock scoffed and declared he needed no help to be magnificent. Later, a storm stripped him of his radiant plumes. Shamed and featherless, he realized his arrogance had left him with nothing but regret.

fable1: A dog was pacing around in the barn, growling and snapping at the cows and thus preventing them from eating the hay that their owner left for them. Annoyed, one of the cows said to her sisters: "How selfish this dog is! He canâ€™t eat the hay, so he puts in all this effort to prevent us from enjoying it."
fable2: Once, a sour grape vine grew beside a tall apple tree. Jealous of the tree's sweet fruits, the grape vine wrapped itself around the tree in an attempt to stop its growth. But the vine couldn't reach the apples, nor could it stunt the tree's growth. Instead, the vine began to wither, while the apple tree continued to flourish.

fable1: A charcoal-burner, who practiced his trade in his own backyard, asked his friend if he would like to come and live with him. His friend, a launderer by profession, said in response: "This would be impossible, as whatever I wheaten would soon be turned black by your charcoal."
fable2: Once a lonely, kind-hearted Sparrow found a wounded butterfly, nursed it back to health and set it free. In appreciation, the Butterfly brought a host of beautiful fluttering friends to keep the Sparrow company. Thus, the bird's kindness was rewarded in kind.

fable1: The rabbits, tired of being so timid and scared all of the time, decided to collectively end their lives by jumping off a tall cliff into a deep lake below. As their large group approached the edge of the cliff, the toads living on the banks of the lake became alarmed by the sound of their feet and quickly fled to safety. Observing the flight of the toads, one of the rabbits ordered the others to stop: "Wait, my friends! Maybe we should not go through with our plan, afer all, as there are clearly creatures who are even more easily scared than we are."
fable2: Once, a small bird with a broken wing sat weeping in the forest. A passing deer, starving and weak, saw the bird and said, "At least you can still find food, I can barely walk." A nearby snake, blinded and lost, overheard them and hissed, "Consider yourselves lucky, at least you both know where you are."

fable1: "Papa," said the small toad to the larger one sitting by the side of a pond, "Yesterday, I came across a huge monster! It was the size of a mountain, had giant horns and a long tail, as well as hoofs that were split in two." "Donâ€™t be alarmed, child", replied the older toad, "that was just an oxen. There are many of those around the farms. Itâ€™s not nearly as big as you say, either. Indeed, I could make myself just as big as him. Let me show you." Having said that, he inhaled a lot of air and blew himself out. "Was he as big as I am now?", he asked his son. "No, he was much bigger than that!" replied the smaller toad. The father drew in even more air, and asked again if the oxen had been as big as he now was. "Even bigger than this, father!" was the reply. So the toad took one last deep breath and burst with a loud pop.
fable2: Once upon a time, a proud peacock, fascinated by his own reflection, would often strut on the edge of a high cliff to admire his grandeur. One day, in his vanity, he spread his feathers wide and leaned forward to get a better look at his reflected glory. He was so absorbed in his own beauty, he failed to notice the crumbling edge. And so, the peacock, lost in his self-admiration, tumbled down the steep cliff to his doom.

fable1: A farmer was sowing hemp seeds in his field, while around him birds were searching for food to pick off the ground. Among the birds was a single magpie, who warned the others to pick up every single one of the hemp seeds or they would regret not having done so. However, the other birds ignored her warning. Soon, the hemp grew up and was turned into cord, from which the farmer made nets to capture many of the birds that didnâ€™t listen to the magpie.
fable2: In a lush garden, a gardener discovered an unusual seed. Intrigued by its uniqueness, he planted the seed, ignoring the warnings of his wise old friend about the potential dangerous plant it could produce. As the seed grew, it slowly began to consume the other plants, stealing their nutrients and sunlight. Too late, the gardener realized the true nature of the plant, but it had grown too strong and overtook the entirety of his beloved garden.

fable1: In a war between mice and cats, the cats were always victorious. The mice assumed that the reason for their defeats was the lack of military leadership to command them and improve their morale. Thus, they elected those among them known for their heritage, strength, and wisdom as their leaders, as well as those who were the bravest fighters, to train up the mouse army. Once the mice completed their drills and felt sufficiently disciplined, they challenged the cats to another battle. Prior to the engagement, the newly elected mouse generals bound straws around their heads to be better seen by their troops on the battlefield. Yet despite all the preparations, the cats emerged victorious yet again, quickly routing the mice who retreated to their holes. The generals, however, could not fit inside the holes due to their headdress and were eaten by the cats as a result.
fable2: Once, a courageous ant won the title of the bravest in the kingdom for fighting a beetle. His fame spread far and wide. One day, a cunning spider, envious of the ant's honor, challenged him to a duel. Blinded by pride, the ant accepted, not knowing that the spider’s web was stronger than any beetle.

fable1: Soaring through the air on a hot Summer day, the sparrow was nearly dying of thirst, when he saw a bottle of water painted on a signboard. Confusing the picture for the real thing, he flew towards the bottle with much speed and smashed against the board, injuring himself gravely. With both wings broken by the impact, he fell to the ground, but was caught by a passerby.
fable2: Once, a young gazelle, overexcited about proving his speed, raced ahead of the herd, ignoring the elder's warnings. Too consumed in his speed, he didn't notice the hidden lion's den and ran straight into it. His speed did not save him then.

fable1: Walking through a vineyard, a hungry raccoon saw a cluster of ripe, dark grapes hanging from a vine just out of his reach. Try as he might, the raccoon was unable to grab the grapes and soon gave up, exhausted. As he walked away from the vine, he said to himself: "These grapes are sour anyway, and not nearly ripe enough.", to hide his disappointment.
fable2: The fox, full of pride and vanity, spotted the luscious grapes hanging high above. He leaped with all his might but could not reach them. He tried climbing and jumping, but they remained elusive. Exhausted and bitter, he remarked, "Those grapes are surely sour and unfit for a fox of my taste," and sauntered off with his nose in the air.

fable1: Having been bitten by a rabid dog, a man went to search for someone who may heal him. Learning about his injury, a friend of his advised him to dip a piece of bread into the blood from his wound and feed it to the dog who bit him, as this would surely cure him. The bite victim laughed at this suggestion, saying: "Why would I do something like that? It would be like inviting every dog in the village to bite me."
fable2: Once upon a time, a kind-hearted rabbit found a snake lying frozen in the snow. With compassion, the rabbit brought the snake into his home, warming him by the fire. As a token of gratitude, the snake promised to never harm the rabbit. However, as soon as the snake revived, he bit his host. The rabbit, in his dying breath, lamented his trust in a known foe.

fable1: The rabbit was a very popular animal and many of the forest creatures claimed to be her friends. One day, she heard the sound of dogs approaching from a distance which scared her greatly, as it was rabbit hunting season. Thus, she decided to escape them with the help of her many friends. First, she asked the horse to carry her to safety. The horse, however, refused his help, since he had work to do and felt sure that the rabbit would be helped by her other friends. Next, she asked the oxen to drive away the dogs away with his mighty horns, but he, too, refused to help, saying that he had already made plans with a lady friend of his. "The ram will certainly help you", he said, before turning away from the rabbit. The ram refused to help, as well, since the same dogs were known to attack sheep as well as rabbits. Almost out of time and options, the rabbit finally asked the calf for his help, but the young animal was uncomfortable with accepting such responsibility, seeing as so many adults declined to take on the task. Soon enough, the dogs arrived in the forest, but by then the rabbit had run away without anyoneâ€™s assistance.
fable2: Once upon a time, a shallow river flowed through a forest, boasting to all the trees about the many pebbles it carried. One day a storm came, causing the river to swell and flush away all the pebbles. After the storm, the river was left without a single pebble, proving that its vast collection was superficial and fleeting.

fable1: A man owned two dogs - one to help him hunt and one to keep him company at home. After each successful hunt, he gave the house dog a large portion of the spoils, which irritated the hunting dog. Thus, the hunting dog said to the house dog: "It frustrates me that I have to work so hard to chase down the prey, while you get to enjoy the fruits of my labor without having contributed to the hunt.". To that, the house dog replied: "Do not blame me, but blame our master, instead. After all, he hasnâ€™t taught me how to work for my food, but raised me to depend on others for my sustenance."
fable2: Once upon a time, a young sapling sprouted in a forest beside a crooked old tree. The forest animals often teased the young tree, ridiculing her, for they assumed she would grow crooked just like her parent. However, as years passed, the sapling matured into a strong, tall, and perfectly straight tree, surprising the forest animals. They learned that a tree's growth is determined by its own efforts and conditions, not by the shape of its parent.

fable1: It happened once that a tiger fell in love with a young woman and proposed a marriage to her parents. Understandably, the old couple didnâ€™t want to give up their daughter to the tiger, but also didnâ€™t want to anger the dangerous predator. Thus, they offered him a compromise: "While we are very honored by you offer, we are afraid that you might injure our daughter when showing your affection, as she is young and tender. We would feel much safer and happily reconsider your proposal if you had your teeth and claws removed to reduce the possible dangers to her." The tiger, blind with love, promptly had his claws cut and teeth taken out. When he next met the parents of his beloved, they laughed at him and simply ignored him, as he no longer posed any threat.
fable2: Once upon a time, a ferocious lion roamed the forest, feared by all creatures. A small, brave sparrow, instead of flying away, sang a sweet song to the lion every day. Over time, the lion grew fond of the sparrow and her song. One day, hunters came for the lion, but the sparrow warned him and saved his life. From that day forward, the lion, once the terror of the forest, lived in harmony with all creatures, his heart tamed by the small sparrow's song and her brave act of love.

fable1: A singing bird, confined to a cage hanging outside a window, made a habit of only singing at night, when no other bird was awake. One night, a bat was flying through the area and heard the birdâ€™s song. Curious, he asked the bird why she sang at night, unlike the other birds. The bird replied: "When I last sang during the daytime, my voice attracted a birdcatcher who trapped me and placed me inside this cage. Ever since then, I only sing at night." Puzzled, the bat replied: "What difference does it make, now that youâ€™re a prisoner? If you had only sung at night before you were caught, you would still have your freedom."
fable2: Once, a small bird lived high in a tree. One day, a storm brewed, and his friend, the squirrel, advised him to secure his nest. The bird ignored him, enjoying the calm before the storm. The storm raged, whisking away his nest. After the storm, the bird spent days rebuilding what he lost, lamenting his earlier inaction.

fable1: A donkey heard the melodic chirping of grasshoppers while passing through a meadow and wanted to become just as talented of a musician as they were. Thus, he asked them what food they were eating, to have such pretty voices. The grasshoppers replied that they eat nothing but dew. In his wisdom, the donkey tried to survive on dew alone, but soon starved to death.
fable2: A hare, known for his boastful speed, snoozed lazily while a slow tortoise passed by. Seeing the tortoise, the hare laughed and challenged him to a race. The tortoise, accepting, plodded along slowly and steadily. The hare, confident in his victory, decided to take a nap. When he awoke, he found the tortoise had won the race. The hare, in his regret, understood the value of steadiness over haste.

fable1: On their journey along the seashore, a group of travellers climbed on top of a tall cliff, and spotted an object approaching them in the distance, believing it to be a ship. They decided to stay and watch it enter the harbor, but as it came closer, the object started to resemble a small boat, rather than a large ship. As it finally reached the beach, driven by the wind, it turned out to be nothing more than a bundle of sticks. Disappointed, one of the travellers remarked: "We have waited here for no reason, as there was nothing to see here other than a pile of driftwood."
fable2: A young rabbit, enchanted by the stories of his elder's adventures, eagerly awaited his first leap into the world. The day came and he hopped out, expecting a world of excitement and endless carrots. His expectations met harsh reality when he found that the world was not only full of carrots but also foxes.

fable1: Witnessing his might, a hawk proposed an alliance to a tiger, so that they may help each other with hunting their prey. The tiger had no objections, but required some proof of the hawkâ€™s good intentions, saying: "How can I trust someone to be a friend who could simply fly away from this alliance whenever it suits him?"
fable2: Once, a charming snake promised a small frog safe passage across the river. Blinded by the snake's charisma, the frog agreed, hopping onto the snake's back. But midway, the snake betrayed the frog and swallowed him whole. The frog's last thought was regret for his misplaced trust.

fable1: A donkey was enjoying the sun in the company of a rooster, when a famished tiger approached them with the intention to find his next meal. Before the tiger could attack the donkey, the rooster crowed loudly, scaring the predator and causing him to flee as fast as he could. Seeing how terrified the tiger was, the donkey decided to chase after him, intending to kick him for threatening his life. After they ran a long distance, the tiger turned around and pounced on the donkey, who soon perished from his wounds.
fable2: Once, a young hare, known for his swiftness, grew so arrogant that he challenged the wind to a race. He boasted loudly, "I'm the fastest in the land. Even you, Wind, cannot beat me!" The wind, silent and calm, simply started to blow. The hare bolted, racing against the wind, but his overconfidence led him off the safe path and straight into a thorny bush. He remained stuck there, whimpering, while the wind gently blew past.

fable1: Chopping down a tree, a woodsman accidentally dropped his ax into the nearby lake. As the lake was very deep, he was unable to retrieve his tool and sat down on the bank, mourning its loss. Suddenly, Hermes appeared before the woodsman and asked him about the reason for his sadness. After learning about his misfortune, Hermes retrieved a golden ax from the lake, asking the woodsman if it was his. Hearing the woodsman say that it was not, Hermes retrieved a second ax from the lake, one made of silver. The woodsman again said that this was not his tool. Finally, Hermes pulled out the woodmanâ€™s ax from the water, who was overjoyed and identified the tool as his own. To reward his honesty, Hermes gave the woodsman all three axes to keep. Some time later, the woodsman told his friends about his encounter with Hermes. One of them headed straight to the same lake, threw his own ax into it, and waited for Hermes to arrive. As before, the god recovered a golden ax from the lake first. Driven by greed, the woodsmanâ€™s friend claimed it to be his right away. Upset by his dishonesty, Hermes took away the golden ax way from him and disappeared, without recovering the manâ€™s own tool.
fable2: Once upon a time, a small bird found a shiny gold coin and decided to hide it. A cunning fox, who saw the bird hide the coin, asked the bird about the shiny object, but the bird denied having anything. Later, a kind owl came by and asked the same. The bird decided to trust the owl and revealed its treasure. Impressed by the bird's honesty, the owl shared a secret about how to find more gold coins. Soon, the bird was richer than ever, while the fox was left with nothing.

fable1: A rabbit, who was a fast runner, once made fun of a tortoise for her slow and measured gait. The tortoise laughed, saying: "As fast as you may be, I will easily beat you in a race." The rabbit quickly accepted the challenge, thinking that it would be impossible for him to lose and asked the raccoon to choose the course and decide on the goal. On the day of the race, the two competitors started running together. But while the tortoise never stopped, slowly and steadily advancing toward the goal, the rabbit laid down by the wayside to take a nap and fell fast asleep. When he finally awoke, he rushed to the goal, but the tortoise has already crossed the finish line by then.
fable2: Once upon a time, a speedy rabbit taunted a tortoise for his slow pace. Accepting the rabbit's challenge to a race, the tortoise plodded along steadily, while the overconfident rabbit decided to nap midway. Waking up to find the tortoise nearing the finish line, the rabbit raced as fast as he could, but the tortoise had already crossed the finish line.

fable1: An angler, after spending the whole day fishing, only caught one small fish. The fish begged him to spare her, saying: "I am far too small to make a filling meal for you right now. Let me go and I will grow, so that you can catch me later when I can satisfy your hunger." The angler smiled and replied: "I think I will keep you, little fish. I have you now, but I may not be able to catch you later."
fable2: Once upon a time, a hungry sparrow found a single seed on the ground. As she prepared to eat it, a crow came by and said, "Ignore that measly seed. Follow me to a far-off field full of ripe grain." The sparrow, enticed by the promise, followed the crow and left the seed behind. But the field was guarded by a fierce farmer and his dog, preventing the birds from getting to the grain. The sparrow returned home, only to find the single seed gone, taken by another bird.

fable1: Once upon a time, there was a wealthy man who hid all of his gold at the foot of an apple tree in his garden. But every now and then he would dig it up to admire his wealth. A thief soon noticed his strange behaviour and, after finding out the location of the gold, dug it up one night and took it for himself. When next visiting his hoard, the wealthy man only found an empty hole, which caused him to cry out in anguish. Hearing his cries, one of the manâ€™s neighbors asked what caused him such distress and thus learned about the gold hoard. "Did you ever use your gold for anything?", the neighbor asked. When the man replied that he only admired it, the neighbor said: "You may as well admire the empty hole, as it will accomplish just as much."
fable2: In a deep forest lived a golden goose named Gilbert. He was capable of laying a golden egg every day, yet Gilbert kept all his eggs hidden in a secret nest. One day, a terrible forest fire broke out, and Gilbert could not save his secret treasure. So, despite owning a trove of golden eggs, he found himself with nothing, just like the other animals of the forest.

fable1: A fox was playing with her pups one sunny morning when she saw a lioness doting on her only cub. "Why care so much about a single cub?", inquired the fox, adding: "See how many babies I have and try to imagine just how proud of a mother I am!" The lioness responded with a sharp look and an upturned nose, saying only: "Yes, you may have many children, but they are only foxes. My child, on the other hand, is a lion."
fable2: In a secluded forest, two woodpeckers had a competition to see who could drill the most holes. The first woodpecker drilled a hundred tiny, shallow holes, while the second woodpecker took its time to carve a single, deep hole. When winter came, the second woodpecker's hole sheltered it from the frost, while the first woodpecker's holes filled with ice and provided no refuge.

fable1: A birdcatcher didnâ€™t have much success that day and was about to have a small dinner of herbs and vegetables, when a friend came to visit. Since his traps were empty, he decided to kill a partridge that he used as a decoy. The bird begged him to spare her, saying that he wouldnâ€™t be able to catch birds in the future without her help, nor fall asleep to her relaxing chirps. The birdcatcher saw reason in her words and instead decided to butcher a young rooster whom he kept in his yard. The rooster, too, pleaded with his owner, saying that without his crawling, the birdcatcher wouldnâ€™t know  when to collect his traps, nor would he be able to rise early in the morning. Having heard him out, the birdcatcher finally said: "Your words make sense. However, my friend and I are hungry and must have our meal."
fable2: In the heart of winter, a starving fox spotted a lush vineyard beyond a high wall. Despite the wall's daunting height, the fox, driven by hunger, found a way to climb over. He feasted on the ripe grapes until his belly was full. When the vineyard owner discovered the fox, he marveled at the creature's resourcefulness rather than scolding its trespassing.

fable1: A tiger was stirred from his afternoon nap by a mouse running across his face. Angered, he grabbed the mouse with his paws and was about to snap her neck, when the mouse asked him for mercy. "If you spare me, I will make sure to return the favour in the future.", said the mouse. Amused by the notion of a mouse saving his life, the tiger laughed and let her go. A couple of days later, the tiger wandered into a trap laid by a group of hunters, who bound him with strong ropes to a tree. As the tiger roared in frustration, the mouse recognized his voice and bit through the ropes with her sharp teeth, thus saving him from a certain death.
fable2: In a forest, a mouse freed a trapped lion by gnawing through the net. The lion, though mighty and powerful, remembered this kindness. When hunters later caught the mouse, the lion swiftly pounced, scattering the hunters and freeing the mouse, repaying the small act of kindness with a great one.

fable1: Upset at the leisurely life of the stomach, other members of the body rose up against him, accusing him to do nothing but rest and enjoy the food, while they toil to satisfy its wants and needs. To prove their point, they resolved not to provide any more assistance to the stomach, which ended up hurting the entire body, as it was now deprived of the neccessary nutrients. The hands, feet, ears, eyes, and mouth eventually recognized their error, but by then it was too late.
fable2: Once upon a time, a bustling beehive was thrown into chaos when the worker bees decided to rule instead of the queen bee. They abandoned their duties of gathering nectar, building combs, and feeding larvae. However, without their contributions, the hive quickly fell into disarray. The queen, unable to gather nectar or build combs, could not sustain the hive. Realising their mistake, the workers returned to their duties, restoring harmony in the kingdom.

fable1: A boy, nearly drowning in a river after having exerted himself too much, called out to a passerby for help. Instead of reaching out and pulling the boy ashore, the passerby scolded him for his thoughtlessness, telling the boy that he should have been more careful. The boy replied while trying to stay afloat: "Please, help me first and scold me later all you want!"
fable2: A hungry mouse discovered a basket full of corn. He sought the owl's wisdom who suggested, "Eat one corn a day, and your food will last longer." The mouse agreed but asked, "How do I reach the corn, it's too high for me?" The owl replied, "That's your problem to solve," and flew away. Struggling and starving, the mouse could only gaze at the unreachable feast above.

fable1: The stableboy took great effort in grooming and rubbing down his masterâ€™s horse, but also regularly stole the oats given to the horse as food, and sold them for his own benefit. After not receiving enough food for weeks, the horse eventually complained to the stableboy: "If you want me to be in good condition, you should spend more time feeding me than grooming me."
fable2: Once, a charming fox invited a gullible rabbit into his luxurious burrow for a feast. The rabbit, dazzled by the fox's warm smile and gracious invitation, excitedly accepted. Inside the burrow, the rabbit found no feast, but became one himself.

fable1: For a long time, the tiger tried to feed on the three oxen who always grazed together not far from his cave. But, afraid of their sharp horns, he did not dare attack them while they could protect each other. Eventually, he devised a clever ruse to turn the bulls against one another and once they went their separate ways, the tiger attacked and devoured them one by one.
fable2: Once upon a time, in a forest, there were five brothers who were rabbits. They always fought and never got along. One day, a hungry wolf spotted them. Individually, they were no match for the wolf, and one by one, they started to get captured. Before the last rabbit was caught, he had an idea and quickly united his brothers. Working together, they tricked the wolf and escaped. From that day forward, they never fought and always stayed together.

fable1: As he passed by a hut, the coyote saw through its window two shepherds dining on fresh mutton chops. Poking his head through the widow, he said: "How upset both of you would get if I ever tried to do have the same meal!"
fable2: Once a proud rooster, known for his loud crowing, ruled over a barnyard. One day, a parrot was introduced into his kingdom. The parrot, mimicking the rooster, began to crow loudly too. The rooster, irate at the parrot's noise, called a barnyard meeting to complain about the parrot's disruption. "Such noise is unacceptable," the rooster proclaimed, while the animals exchanged knowing glances.

fable1: A tiger and bear caught a deer at the same time, and ended up fighting for the right to claim the prey as theirs. The fight was long and caused both animals much injury, so that both eventually collapsed on the ground, with no energy left to move. A coyote, who had been observing the battle from a safe distance, realized that neither the tiger nor the bear were in a good enough shape to claim the deer. Thus, he quickly ran between them, seized their prey, and ran off to enjoy his meal away from the wounded predators.
fable2: Once, a donkey worked day and night to carry heavy sacks to the market for a lazy merchant. The merchant, while doing nothing himself, sold the goods at a high price. One day, the donkey collapsed from exhaustion and could no longer work. The merchant was left with nothing to sell and starved, while the freed donkey found greener pastures elsewhere.

fable1: A great hero, traversing a narrow road, came across a strange-looking beast that tried to attack him as soon as he came within its reach. The hero, in defence, pummeled it with his club and expected the fight to be over. The beast, however, grew three times bigger, and seemed even more threatening to the hero. He, however, remained unafraid and attacked the monster again and again, and with each blow the monster seemed to grow larger still, until it completely blocked the road. At the last moment, Athena appeared before the hero and said: "Stop! This monster is called Strife. Ignore it, and it will soon shrink to its initial size."
fable2: Two neighboring trees, an Oak and a Pine, constantly competed for sunlight. They argued, each claiming the right to the sun's warmth. One day, a wily vine heard their bickering, and promised to settle the dispute. Using the trees' ongoing disagreement as a distraction, the vine began to climb both trees. By the time the Oak and Pine realized what was happening, they were both overgrown, their sunlight stolen by the vine they had allowed to thrive.

fable1: A dog was chasing a rabbit on behalf of his master but, after a long pursuit, eventually gave up. A shepherd who had been observing the chase ridiculed the dog, saying that the rabbit was clearly the better runner of the two. The dog, however, replied: "It is not fair to compare us, since I was running to please my master, while the rabbit was running to save her life."
fable2: In a dense forest, a timid rabbit was cornered by a hungry fox. The rabbit, who had never burrowed before, desperately clawed at the earth and, to his surprise, quickly created a tunnel to escape. The fox was left pawing at the dirt as the rabbit found safety underground.

fable1: On his journey to a distant country, the traveller hired a donkey and his owner to help him cross a particularly dry and inhospitable stretch of land. Eventually, the group had to stop to rest, and with the sun shining down mercilessly on them, the traveller sought respite from the heat in the donkeyâ€™s shadow, which was just big enough for one man. The owner of the donkey objected, claiming that the traveller hired only the donkey, and thus had no right to enjoy the shade, while the traveller insisted that by hiring the donkey he also paid for his shadow. The disagreement eventually turned violent, leading from words to blows, and causing the donkey to run off in fear.
fable2: Two dogs found a bone and began to fight over who spotted it first. Their argument escalated into a full-blown quarrel, leading to snapping and growling. While they were busy fighting, a larger dog noticed the bone lying unattended. He quickly grabbed it and ran off, leaving the two smaller dogs still squabbling, oblivious to their lost prize.

fable1: One time, the sun and the wind were debating which one of them was the strongest. As they quarreled, they saw a traveller come down a road and the sun suggested that whoever manages to make the traveller take off his cloak would be considered the strongest of them both. The wind started by blowing as hard as he could, but that only made the traveller wrap his cloak tighter around his shoulders, until the wind finally gave up. The sun, in turn, shone warm rays of light upon the traveller. Feeling hot, he soon took of his cloak to feel more comfortable, thus handing the victory to the sun.
fable2: Once, a sun and a wind made a wager to see who could make a man remove his coat quicker. The wind blew fiercely, but the man only clutched his coat tighter. Then, the sun shone gently, making the man feel warm and comfortable, so he happily took off his coat.

fable1: A farmer was once driving a heavily-laden wagon along a muddy road. Eventually, the road got so bad that the wagonâ€™s wheels sank half-way into the mud and the wagon became completely stuck. The farmer, not knowing what else to do, knelt down and prayed for gods to help him out of this predicament. Zeus heard his prayer and appeared before him, but rather than moving the wagon he said to the farmer: "Donâ€™t just kneel there, man! Instead, get up and start pushing the wagon."
fable2: In a dense forest lived a lazy rabbit who never gathered food for winter. One day, he prayed to the forest god for food. The god, moved by his prayer, guided him to a bush laden with berries. But instead of picking the berries, the rabbit waited for the berries to fall. Winter came, the rabbit starved, while the industrious squirrels feasted on the berries they had gathered.

fable1: A man had two daughters - one married a gardener and the other married a brick maker. The father would regularly check up on both daughters and ask them how they fared, since he loved them both equally. When he visited the daughter who married the gardener, she said that everything is well, but she hoped for heavy rainfall to help with the watering of plants. On his visit to the other daughter, she also was happy with the overall state of things, but wished for the dry weather to continue, as it made the bricks dry faster. The father was happy for both of his daughters, but also torn, since he did not know whether he should be wishing for a wet of dry season.
fable2: A squirrel, in its generosity, decided to give a feast. It served nuts for the birds, but they complained about the hardness. Wary, the squirrel served berries for the hedgehogs, but they grumbled about the sweetness. Troubled, the squirrel served leaves for the rabbits, but they moaned about the blandness. Exhausted and disheartened, the squirrel realized that no matter what it served, there would always be someone who found fault.

fable1: After breaking into a house, the thief could not find anything of value inside other than a rooster, so he took the bird with him and fled. When he got home, he started preparations to slaughter the bird and have him for dinner. The rooster, having noticed his intentions, pleaded for mercy: "Please, spare my life! I am a very useful bird, as I wake up people every night, so that they may get to work on time." "This makes me want to kill you even more", replied the thief, "because whenever youâ€™re waking up people, youâ€™re also making it more difficult for me to do my work."
fable2: Once, a cunning fox attempted to enter a peaceful henhouse. But, a wise guard dog, knowing the fox's intentions, had set up a series of traps. The fox, frustrated by the obstacles, cursed the dog's precautions. Meanwhile, the hens continued their lives undisturbed.

fable1: The coyote, having noticed a lamb that strayed far away from her flock, decided that he should justify to the lamb his right to eat her, instead of simply attacking her. Therefore, he said to the lamb: "I remember that you insulted me most gravely last year!". The lamb replied that she was not even born back then. The coyote thus came up with another lie: "Clearly, you are grazing on my pasture!" The lamb, however, retorted that she has never even tasted grass, due to her young age. Exasperated, the coyote said: "Well, then youâ€™re drinking from my well!" In response, the lamb pointed out that she only drank her motherâ€™s milk. Fed up, the coyote picked up the lamb and swallowed her, saying: "Well, despite your convincing arguments, I choose not to remain without dinner."
fable2: Once a lion ruled the forest, claiming his strength kept order. One day, a brave rabbit questioned his rule. The lion roared, "I'm the only one who can protect you from the wolves!" The next day, the rabbit returned, clarifying there were no wolves in their forest. The lion, without missing a beat, hissed, "Then, I must protect you from the bears!"

fable1: A hunter, who was not especially brave, was tracking a tiger through a forest. There, he came across a woodsman and asked him if he knew the location of the tigerâ€™s cave. The woodsman offered to bring him to the cave right away, as he knew exactly where it was. The hunter, clearly startled and shaking with fear, replied: "Thank you for your kind offer, but Iâ€™m only interested in the tigerâ€™s track and not the animal itself."
fable2: Once a small village was being terrorized by a ferocious dragon. A boastful knight, known for his grand stories, quickly fled in fear when faced with the beast. It was the quiet blacksmith, who seldom spoke much but had courage in his heart, who forged a great sword and faced the dragon, liberating the village from its fear.

fable1: In the middle of a garden stood an apple tree that bore no fruit, but served as a home to many birds and insects. The owner of the garden decided to fell the tree, as it was of no use to him. After he hit the trunk with his ax for the first time, the inhabitants of the tree begged him not to cut it down, as it gave them shelter, and offered to help the owner with his work in exchange. The man ignored their pleas and continued striking the tree, until his ax exposed a hive filled with honey that was hidden within a hollow in the treeâ€™s trunk. Having tasted the honey, the man immediately dropped his ax and took good care of the tree ever since.
fable2: Once a river, brimming with fish, ran through a village where two men lived. One was a fisherman who caught only enough for his meals. The other, a merchant, saw the river and thought only of the fortune he could make. He set up a large net, catching all the fish until the river was empty. When the fisher went to catch his dinner, he found nothing. The village starved, the merchant grew rich, while the fisherman starved with the rest.

fable1: A young mule, after spending the whole day eating and relaxing, galloped around his enclosure in high spirits, thinking to himself that surely his father must have been a race horse. After all, how else could his own grace and energy be explained? On the next day, however, after having been driven for many hours on a long and arduous journey, he admitted to himself that his father could not have been anything but a donkey.
fable2: Once, a squirrel and a rabbit watched a coin fall from a man's pocket. The squirrel, viewing from a tree, insisted it landed heads up. The rabbit, on the ground, argued it was tails. After much dispute, they approached the coin and saw it was standing on its edge, showing both heads and tails. To their surprise, they realized they were both right, and wrong, at the same time.

fable1: A shepherd longed to make a journey across the sea that often occupied his thoughts while he was herding his sheep. Thus, he sold his flock and invested the proceeds in crates of dates, to sell at his destination. While the first days of the voyage were calm, a violent storm soon caught up with the ship. To prevent the ship from sinking, the shepherd threw all of the cargo overboard, barely escaping with his life on the empty vessel. Having at last arrived at his destination, he heard a passerby remark how calm the sea is. "Aye, the sea wants more dates and thus pretends to be quiet.", was his reply.
fable2: In a lush forest, lived a cunning fox that always wore a halo of flowers, fooling the animals into thinking he was a saint. One day, a naive rabbit approached him, entrusting the fox with his winter stock of carrots. The fox gratefully accepted, promising to safeguard them. When winter hit, the rabbit returned, only to find the fox fat and his carrots gone.

fable1: Tired of being slaughtered, the bulls one day decided to destroy the butchers who were causing great harm to their race. Thus, they assembled one day to discuss the plan of attack and sharpen their horns. Among them, was one particularly old bull who plowed many fields in his life. Seeing his brothers ready themselves, he said: "While it is true that the butchers are slaughtering our kind, they do so skillfully. If we destroy them, then unskilled workers will take over their role, causing us much greater pain as they kill us. For even if all butchers should perish, men will always crave the taste of beef."
fable2: A small mouse, tired of the constant danger of the cat, pleaded with the wizard. The wizard, obliging, transformed him into a bird, free in the sky. But soon, the mouse-turned-bird found himself under a greater threat - the swooping hawk.

fable1: A peacock, spreading his by all accounts beautiful tail, made fun of a stork who was resting under a nearby tree, saying: "Behold, my feathers are like the finest clothes of royalty, I am dressed in all colors of the rainbow, while your wings are dull and empty of color." Amused, the stork retorted: "True as that may be, I soar into the heavens and past the clouds, and speak to the stars at my leisure, while you are stuck down below like a common chicken."
fable2: In the kingdom of birds, a crow discovered a box of precious gold feathers. She adorned herself with them and strutted around, boasting of her newfound beauty. But when a storm hit, the heavy gold feathers failed to keep her aloft. The other birds, with their plain but strong feathers, soared high, leaving the gold-clad crow struggling on the ground.

fable1: Zeus announced that he intended to appoint the most beautiful of birds as king to reign over the rest, naming a day on which this decision would be made. In preparation, all birds retreated to a lake shore to wash and groom their feathers. Among them was a jackdaw, who was well-aware that his drab plumage wonâ€™t make him royalty. So he waited until the rest of the birds had left the shore, collected the prettiest of the feathers they left behind, and fashioned them into a dress that made him appear more beautiful than the rest of the birds. On the appointed day, all birds presented themselves to Zeus, who recognized the jackdaw as the prettiest among them. But just as he was about to crown the new bird king, the other birds tore the jackdaw's dress apart, exposing hs true, boring plumage.
fable2: Once, a peacock and a nightingale lived in the same forest. The peacock always boasted about his colorful feathers, whereas the nightingale was plain and brown. One day, a fire broke out in the forest. The peacock, frightened, only flew around in panic, while the nightingale's song guided all the animals to safety.

fable1: By an unlucky coincidence, a land-dwelling mouse befriended a toad who spent most of his time in a pond. One day, the toad intended to play a prank on the mouse and tied one of her legs tightly to one of his own. Unable to escape the toad, the mouse was first dragged to the meadows where the two usually found their food. Afterwards, however, the toad headed straight for the pond and jumped into the water, dragging the mouse along with him. While the toad enjoyed himself in the water, swimming and diving across the pond, the poor mouse soon suffocated as she never learned to swim. Her lifeless body floated to the surface and soon attracted the attention of a buzzard, who swooped down and grabbed it with his claws. Since the frog was still attached to his former friend, he too was carried into the sky and soon eaten by the buzzard.
fable2: Once, a mischievous little boy found a nest with a single egg. Despite knowing it was wrong, he wickedly decided to break it open. The moment he did, out flew a baby Phoenix, which in its fright, ignited a flame that set the boy's shirt on fire. After putting out the flames, the boy learned his lesson about the consequences of causing harm.

fable1: A donkey, driven along a road high in the mountains, suddenly ran towards the brink of a cliff overlooking a deep chasm. Just as he was about to jump off the cliff, his owner grabbed him by the tail, trying to pull the animal back. However, as the donkey persisted in his efforts, the owner eventually let go of him, saying: "Conquer, but be aware of the cost."
fable2: Once upon a time, a stubborn donkey followed a path that led to a dangerous cliff. His master, out of concern, tried to steer him away, but the donkey refused to obey. Despite the master's warnings, the donkey continued on. Ultimately, he fell off the cliff, meeting a tragic end.

fable1: When he first encountered a camel, the man was frightened by his size and quickly ran away. After a while, he noticed that the animal was exceptionally gentle and did not wish him any harm, and summoned enough courage to finally approach him. Marvelling at how placid and passive the camel was, the man eventually put a bridle in his mouth and let children ride around on his back.
fable2: Once, a timid mouse was terrified of crossing a wide river, fearing he might drown. He shared his fear with a wise frog who suggested a plan. The frog offered the mouse a ride on his back, and together they crossed the river. The mouse learned that with the help of others, even the most fearsome obstacles can be overcome.

fable1: During a siege on their city, the inhabitants assembled to find the best way of protecting themselves against the enemyâ€™s attacks. A brick maker fully believed bricks to provide the most protection and thus recommended a brick wall. A carpenter, equally convinced to be in the right, recommended the use of timber, instead. Finally, a tanner stood up and proclaimed that he disagrees with his fellow townspeople and that leather and hides alone provide superior protection.
fable2: In the heart of the forest, a lion, a fox, and a rabbit discovered a cache of fruit. The lion, with his mighty roar, claimed the largest portion, the fox, with his cunning, hid a respectable share, and the rabbit, with his timidity, took the least. When a wildfire swept through the forest, the lion was too burdened to escape, the fox was too preoccupied guarding his stash, but the rabbit, light and quick, managed to flee to safety.

fable1: On a warm winterâ€™s day, the ants were busy drying corn that they had collected during summer. While they were engaged in their work, a starving grasshopper passed by and begged them for a single grain to stop his hunger. The ants, in turn, asked him why he had not collected food during the summer to prepare for the harsh winter, to which the grasshopper replied that he spent the warm days singing. Mockingly, the ants said to him in unison: "Since you spent your summer singing, then you must dance hungrily to bed in winter."
fable2: In the heart of the forest, the Squirrel and the Grasshopper lived. All summer, the Squirrel tirelessly gathered acorns for the winter, while the Grasshopper ambled around, basking in the sun. Winter came, and the Grasshopper found himself starving and cold, while the Squirrel was snug and full in his well-stocked burrow.

fable1: A farmer was travelling to the market with a heavily laden donkey and mule. While traversing a plain, both animals carried their load without issue, but as soon as they started climbing a mountain path, the donkey felt that his load was too heavy for him to bear. Struggling, he asked the mule to take over a small part of his load, since he was the stronger of the two, but the mule ignored his plea. Soon enough, the donkey collapsed under the weight and perished. Not knowing what else to do, the farmer placed the entirety of the donkeyâ€™s load onto the mule, in addition to his own, as well as the donkeyâ€™s hide that the farmer intended to sell at their destination. The mule groaned under the extreme weight, regretting not having helped the donkey in the first place.
fable2: In a bustling forest, a wise old owl noticed a tiny ember glowing beneath a parched tree. Ignoring it, the other animals danced and played, saying, "It's just a small ember, it can't harm us." The owl, however, fetched water and doused the ember. The next day, they awoke to the sight of a forest still lush and green, while the news of a devastating wildfire in the neighboring forest reached them.

fable1: A rooster found a shiny gem while pecking around in the dirt to find food for himself and his hens. Looking down at the stone, he observed: "Had your owner found you, he would have picked you up and treasured you. I, however, have no use for you and would have preferred to find some corn, instead. "
fable2: In a small forest, a squirrel found a shiny diamond and, not understanding its value, used it to prop up his wobbly nut storage. Seeing this, an owl offered him an exchange for a handful of nuts. The squirrel, thinking he had the better deal, eagerly agreed, forever unaware of the treasure he had lost.

fable1: Looking at his mother, a young fawn couldnâ€™t help but ask: "Mother, you are larger, faster, and have more endurance than any of the huntersâ€™ hounds. You can also defend us with your horns. Why is it then, that the dogs frighten you this much?" Her mother replied with a sad smile: " What you are saying is certainly true - I do have all of these advantages. However, as soon as I hear a dogâ€™s bark, I feel the need to flee as I may faint, otherwise."
fable2: Once, a timid rabbit was afraid to leave his burrow. His friend, the squirrel, tried to convince him that the world outside was beautiful and safe. He presented all sorts of arguments, from the beauty of the sunrise to the joy of the fresh air, but the rabbit refused to leave, forever entrapped by his own fears.

fable1: A coyote had one day found a sheepskin and decided to disguise himself to get easier access to the shepherdâ€™s flock. Covered by the skin, he grazed together with the sheep and snuck into their enclosure in the evening, which was locked and secured by the shepherd. Just as the coyote was preparing to dine on the defenseless creatures, the shepherd returned to obtain some meat for the next day and, confusing the coyote for a sheep, slaughtered him there and then.
fable2: Once a spiteful serpent decided to inject venom into every fruit in the forest, hoping to harm the animals. However, his first bite was into a reflective apple, causing him to inject venom into himself, leading to his own demise.

fable1: The silkworm received an order for twenty yards of her finest silk from the tigress and, aiming to finish the order as soon as possible, started working at her loom. Some time later, a spider stopped by and wanted to rent a web-room nearby, to which the silkworm agreed. The spider started working on her own project and was soon finished. Observing the methodical labor of the silkworm, the spider remarked, as she was leaving: "Look at how great and delicate my webs are! And it took me a fraction of the time to spin them that it would have taken you. You must admit that Iâ€™m a much better worker than you could ever be." The silkworm replied: "Be quiet - youâ€™re distracting me. In the end, your webs are nothing more than basic traps, destroyed and brushed away as useless dirt whenever they are seen. In contrast, the fruits of my labor are treasured by royalty all over the world."
fable2: Once upon a time, a boastful painter created a grand portrait overnight and flaunted it around the town. A humble sculptor, however, spent years chiseling a beautiful statue in a quiet alley. The painter's work quickly faded and was forgotten, while the sculptor's statue became a beloved landmark, enchanting generations with its beauty and intricate details.

fable1: One evening, the shepherd noticed that one of the rams was missing from his flock. Soon he spotted the ram grazing in the distance and tried to get his attention by whistling and shouting, without success. Finally, he threw a stone at the ram, and hit one of his horns, which shattered on impact. Terrified, the shepherd pleaded with the ram not to tell his master what happened, but the ram replied that his horn will speak for itself, even if he remains silent.
fable2: Once, a vain Star decided to dim its own light to avoid the envy of others. However, even at its dimmest, it still shone brightly in the night sky. When the other stars asked why it tried to hide, the Star could only sigh and continue to shine.

fable1: A rooster was perching on top of a house when he spotted a coyote walk the street below him. Knowing that the coyote wouldnâ€™t be able to reach him, he attacked him with words: "How dare you show yourself so close to the homes of honest people? They all know of your many crimes, you murderer and thief!" Smiling, the coyote replied: "Why donâ€™t you come down here and repeat your accusations to my face?"
fable2: Once, a mouse chattered loudly, proclaiming his bravery and challenging a cat from the safety of his hole. The cat, intrigued, moved away. The mouse, encouraged, ventured out—only to be snatched by an eagle soaring from above.

fable1: While watching his donkey graze in a meadow, the farmer was alerted by what sounded like the cries of an invading force coming from the distance. Alarmed, he told his donkey that they have to flee right away, to which the animal replied: "Why should I flee with you? Do you believe that the enemy will load twice as many bags on my back than you already do?" "No, probably not.", admitted the farmer. "Then, what difference does it make to me whose bags Iâ€™m carrying?", said the animal.
fable2: In a kingdom of beetles, the lowly dung beetle worked tirelessly for the reigning monarch. One day, a charismatic ladybug led a revolution and overthrew the monarch. The dung beetle, hopeful of better days, cheered along with the rest. The next morning, he found himself rolling the same dung, only now, under the watchful eyes of the ladybug.

fable1: A raccoon stumbled by chance into the store room of a theatre. Wandering around, he was suddenly confronted by a face that glared at him from above. Impressed by its beauty, he soon realized that it was just a mask commonly worn by actors during their performances and said: "Although youâ€™re beautiful, itâ€™s a shame that you donâ€™t have any brains."
fable2: Once, a tattered, plain-looking sparrow befriended a peacock, famed for his grand feathers. The peacock, always surrounded by admirers, often belittled the sparrow for her plainness. One stormy day, the peacock's gorgeous feathers got drenched, making him unable to fly. It was the humble sparrow who flew high, seeking help and saving his life. From then on, the peacock was humbled, and he learned to respect all, no matter their appearance.

fable1: One day, the lion went hunting together with the fox, the coyote, and the weasel. They hunted all day long, until eventually they ambushed a moose and quickly subdued him. The lion then demanded that the stagâ€™s body be divided into four parts, which the other animals quickly accomplished. Standing in front of the individual portions of meat, the lion began to assign the portions as he saw fit. The first portion he gave to himself, since he was the king of all animals. The second portion he also claimed for himself, for his role as the judge dividing the spoils. The third portion he assigned to himself also, for doing his part in the hunt. Finally, he dared the other animals to object to his decision to keep the final portion to himself, as well, yet none was brave enough to do so.
fable2: A tiny ant and a powerful lion teamed up to hunt for food. The ant tirelessly found and guided the lion to their prey, while the lion used his strength to make the kill. When it was time to feast, the lion devoured the meal while the ant watched from a distance, receiving only the leftovers.

fable1: A king had a son, who liked to hunt wild beasts. One night, the king dreamt that his son would be killed by a tiger and, afraid that the dream was a prophecy, he built for his son a palace which the prince was not allowed to leave under any circumstances. For the princeâ€™s amusement, the walls of the castle were painted with murals depicting life-size animals, including a ferocious tiger.  When the young prince spotted the tiger, he was reminded that he may never set foot outside the castle again, all because of a dream in which he fell to a tiger just like the one in the mural. Enraged, he reached for the branch of a nearby tree, to use it as a club with which he could destroy the mural. But, in doing so, he cut his finder on one of theeâ€™s many thorns. The wound caused him great pain and eventually became inflamed, causing the prince to faint. He soon developed a fever and died only a few days later.
fable2: Once, a hare was caught in a thorny bush. In fear, he tried to escape hastily, only to get more entangled. A wise old tortoise happened by, and calmly navigated his way through the thorns to help the hare. Free at last, the hare learned the value of courage in the face of adversity.

fable1: A thief had to rent a room at an inn one day and stayed for some time, hoping to steal something that would help him settle the bill. Eventually, he noticed that the innkeeper was wearing a new, fancy coat that would undoubtedly fetch a good price. So the thief sat down with the innkeeper and engaged him in conversation. After some time, he yawned in an exaggerated fashion and howled like a wolf. Surprised, the innkeeper inquired why he would do such a thing. The thief replied: "I will tell you, but youâ€™ll have to hold my clothes or I will tear them to pieces. Iâ€™m not sure when I started yawning like this or what caused this change in behavior, I only know that when I yawn three times in a row, I will turn into a wolf and attack anyone in sight." Once he said this, he immediately yawned and howled a second time. The innkeeper looked visibly alarmed and, planning to run away from the thief, started to stand up. Noticing this, the thief put a hand on the innkeeperâ€™s coat and asked him to stay a while longer to hold his clothes, so that they wonâ€™t get torn when he transforms into a wolf. Just as he was saying this, the thief yawned a third time and howled in a particularly terrifying manner. This scared the innkeeper greatly and, shrugging off his coat to escape the thief's grip, he ran away as fast as he could. The thief, happy with this outcome, took the coat and left the inn never to return.
fable2: A young and naive rabbit once met a cunning fox who claimed he had a garden full of carrots to share. Enthralled by the fox’s fanciful tale, the rabbit followed him home, only to find there were no carrots, and narrowly escaped becoming the fox’s dinner.

fable1: Two toads lived as neighbors in a pond. During a particularly hot summer, the pond dried up and the toads had to find another place to live, as they liked wet places. In their search for a new home, they came across a well with plenty of water in it. Recognizing it as a nice, cool place to live in, one of the toads suggested to his companion that they jump in and make it their new home. The other one, who was older and wiser, replied: "Wait, friend! If the well dried out like our pond did, how would we get out again?"
fable2: Once, a young frog, eager to explore the world, spotted a shiny object at the bottom of a well. Overcome by curiosity and without a second thought, he leapt in to retrieve it. However, once inside, he realized the walls were too steep to climb out. Stuck there, he understood the allure of the shiny object had trapped him.

fable1: The oxen was plowing his ownerâ€™s fields when a pig walked up to him and started pitying the oxen for his endless toils while bragging about her own life of contentment and luxury. Shortly afterwards, the oxen was allowed to rest with the commencement of the annual harvest festival, while the pig was caught and bound with rope by her owner. She was to be sacrificed at the altar to ensure a bountiful harvest. Seeing this, the oxen said to the pig: "It seems that you were only allowed to live an idle life to end up a sacrifice."
fable2: Once, a smug hare challenged a slow tortoise to a race, confident of his win. He raced ahead, leaving the tortoise far behind. Seeing the tortoise's slow pace, he decided to nap, certain he had ample time. He woke to the sight of the tortoise crossing the finish line, his face filled with a victorious smile.

fable1: A young farmer was carrying two buckets filled with milk from the field to her house and began thinking about the future. "Selling this milk will allow me to purchase approximately three hundred eggs. I can reasonably expect two hundred and fifty chickens to hatch from them, who could then be sold when poultry is most in demand. The profits would allow me to buy a beautiful dress by the end of the year which I could wear to fancy Christmas parties. There, I will likely attract the attention of many eligible bachelors. But I will refuse every one of them, tossing my head like so." When she tossed her head to play out the hypothetical scenario, she dropped the buckets, spilling the milk all over the ground and causing her future plans to crumble.
fable2: Once, a young farmer bought a large number of eggs, dreaming of the wealth he would acquire from their chicks. He began to spend extravagantly, even selling his plow to purchase a lavish feast to celebrate his future riches. However, when the eggs didn't hatch as expected, the farmer was left with a grand feast, but no means to farm.

fable1: An old man, suffering from various age-related afflictions, was collecting sticks in the forest to heat his home with. The work was hard and tedious, so eventually he threw down the sticks and cried out that he would rather be dead than endure this hardship any longer. As he spoke, Death himself appeared to him in the form of a skeleton wrapped in a dark cloak, asking the man if it was he who summoned him. Terrified, the man could only mutter in response: "Please, could you help me lift this bundle of sticks back onto my shoulders?"
fable2: A sparrow, tired of flying, wished upon a star to become a cat, envying their lazy lifestyle. The next day, he woke up as a feline and joyously spent the day lazing in the sun. As night fell, he saw his former friends flying home and felt a deep longing. When winter came, he found himself missing the tropical warmth that he could have flown to as a bird.

fable1: A wealthy man was throwing a great feast for his friends and acquaintances. His dog took this opportunity to invite a friend of his own, a stray, to whom he promised plenty of food as there has always been a lot of leftovers on similar occasions in the past. The stray eagerly consented and showed up at the house at the appointed hour. As the two dogs walked through the corridors, the stray got more and more excited about all the food around him, promising himself to eat enough to last him several days, and wagging his tail in appreciation of his thoughtful friend. However, as soon as they reached the kitchen, a cook noticed the stray and, grabbing him by the legs, threw him out of the nearest window. Landing on the hard ground, the dog howled in pain and limped away from the house. Soon, he was approached by other strays who asked him about his visit to his wealthy friend. The stray replied: "To be honest, I donâ€™t remember all of the details. I drank so much wine, I donâ€™t even know how I got out of the house again!"
fable2: In a grand mansion, a crafty fox decided to sneak into a lavish banquet through the kitchen. He gorged on the finest foods, sipped the most exquisite wines, and basked in the music and merriment. But his sneaky entrance hadn't gone unnoticed. The mansion's owner, a wise old owl, spotted the uninvited guest. Without a word, he swooped down, seized the fox and swiftly dropped him out the banquet hall window.

fable1: During one of their regular gatherings, the animals of the forest entertained each other with song and dance. When it was his turn, the orangutan stood up and performed a beautiful and complex dance. The audience, dazzled, showered him in applause as he sat back down. The sloth, envious of the attention the orangutan was receiving and wanting it for himself, stood up and danced next. But, his movements were so ridiculous and uncoordinated that the other animals, offended by such mockery, attacked him and drove him out of their gathering.
fable2: Once, a tiny sparrow, envious of the eagle's majestic flight, attempted to soar as high. Ignoring his own strengths, the sparrow ascended, not noticing the air thinning. Suddenly, he gasped for breath and plummeted, only saved by a fortuitous haystack. He chirped feebly, realizing that soaring like an eagle wasn't meant for a small sparrow.

fable1: A hawk, hunting for dinner, attempted to ambush a snake that he saw crawling along a forest path. The snake noticed the hawk just in time, however, and trapped him in her coils. As the two fought for their respective lives, they were spotted by a woodsman walking along the same path. Without a second thought, he helped the hawk by freeing him from the snake who, in an act of revenge, spat some of her poison into the woodsmanâ€™s drinking horn before crawling away into the grass. As the man was about to quench his thirst after all the excitement, the hawk knocked his horn to the ground, spilling the poison within.
fable2: A small mouse, trapped in a net, was freed by a kindly elephant. Later, the elephant fell into a pit which was too steep for it to climb out of. Remembering the elephant's kindness, the mouse gathered all its fellow mice to nibble away the edge of the pit, allowing the elephant to escape.

fable1: A long time ago, all ducks and swans were able to sing beautiful songs. But, one day, they heard the neigh of a horse and fell so in love with its sound that they spent all of their time trying to imitate it. In their efforts, they eventually forgot their songs and have not managed to remember them to this day.
fable2: Once a contented little bird lived in a lush green forest. One day, she heard a tale about a golden tree in a distant land, said to bear fruits of pure gold. Enthraptured by the possibility of unimaginable wealth, she left her abundant forest and her family in pursuit of this golden tree. She flew for days, then months, facing many hardships and dangers, but found no sign of the golden tree. Exhausted and hungry, she returned home only to find her forest gone, replaced by a city, and her family nowhere to be found.

fable1: A wild boar was rubbing her tusks against the trunk of a tree when a raccoon approached her. Seeing what the boar was doing, he asked: "Why are you sharpening your tasks? The hunting season has not yet started - there is no imminent danger to you." The boar replied: "I do this in preparation. There would be no time to sharpen them when I am being hunted."
fable2: Once upon a time, a vain knight named Cedric spent all his days boasting about his victories and ignoring his duties. One day, a dragon attacked the kingdom. As trumpets blared, signaling the attack, Cedric rushed to find his trusty sword. It was then, he realized his sword was dull from years of neglect. In the heat of the battle, his sword was incapable of piercing the dragon's tough skin, leading to the kingdom's downfall.

fable1: A pelican swallowed a fish that was far too large for his throat and was slowly suffocating as he lay on the sea shore. Flying overhead, a falcon observed: "He got what he deserved. A bird is supposed to hunt in the air, not in the sea."
fable2: Once, in a vast jungle, a curious rabbit often interfered with other animals' affairs. One day, he spotted a lion's den and decided to rearrange it while the lion was away, thinking he was helping. The lion returned, was startled by the change, and in his panic, accidentally injured the rabbit. If only the rabbit had stayed in his own burrow...

fable1: A young boy was tasked with herding a flock of sheep near a village. He quickly grew bored of watching the animals and, to amuse himself, shouted "Wolf! Wolf!", which caused all villagers to come running towards the flock to protect it. When they arrived, the boy only laughed at them for being so gullible. He repeated this several times until, one day, he actually saw a wolf stalking the flock. Despite his cries for help, none of the villagers arrived, as they were fed up with his pranks and no longer believed him. The wolf, facing little opposition, soon decimated the flock.
fable2: Once, a mischievous shepherd boy found amusement in tricking his village by crying wolf, causing them to come running only to find no danger. Amused but weary, the villagers warned him against such pranks. One day, a real wolf appeared, and the boy cried out in genuine fear. However, no villager came, dismissing his cries as another hoax. That day, the boy lost his entire flock to the wolf.

fable1: A crab was tired of living close to the sea and decided to move to the lush, green meadow as his new home. As he was settling in, a coyote discovered him crawling around in the grass and gobbled him up as an afternoon snack. Just before he was eaten, the crab said: " What else did I expect? After all, I traded the home that I was well-adapted to in my nature and habits for this patch of land."
fable2: In a vast forest, a squirrel spent his days collecting acorns, always wanting more. He envied the birds' flight and the fishes' swim. One day, he found a golden acorn granting him one wish. He wished to become a bird. With his new wings, he soared high but soon missed his old life - his cozy tree hollow, his simple acorn meals. He learned too late that he had been happiest as a squirrel.

fable1: A man and a tiger were walking together through the forest, discussing the relative strengths of men and tigers to pass the time. Engaged in their debate, they happened across a statue depicting a tiger being subdued by a man. The traveller pointed at the statue and said: "See? Clearly men must be far stronger than tigers, like this statue shows." The tiger retorted: "If this statue had been made by tigers, and not by men, it would show a tiger clutching a man in his claws."
fable2: A fox was boasting to a rabbit about his cunning and swiftness. "I can outrun any animal in the forest," claimed the fox. The rabbit, seemingly impressed, invited a deer to listen to the fox's story. The deer, with a chuckle, recounted how he had easily outrun the fox many times. The rabbit looked at the fox, who blushed and slunk away in embarrassment.

fable1: A pair of coyotes, nearly dying of hunger, noticed several cowhides drying on the opposite side of a river. Unable to swim across the river due to their weakness, they decided to drink it dry and then walk to the other side. But, long before they were able to get to the hides, they burst after drinking too much of the water.
fable2: Once, a young fish desired to fly like the birds. It flapped its fins tirelessly, leaping out of the water, but always splashing back down. One day, the fish, in its zeal, leapt onto a dry rock and was stranded until a kind bird pushed it back into the water. The next day, the fish started practicing the art of swimming efficiently and became the fastest swimmer in the pond.

fable1: Two toads lived as neighbors not too far away from each other. But while one toad lived in a deep pond hidden away from the public by tall grass, the other inhabited a shallow puddle which was often disturbed by the wheels of passing carriages. The first toad tried several times to convince his neighbor to move in with him, but the latter refused, saying how difficult it would be for him to leave a place he has grown so used to. Soon, an especially heavy wagon passed through the puddle, catching the toad by surprise and squashing him under its wheels.
fable2: Once, a stubborn goat decided to climb the highest, most dangerous peak, ignoring the warnings of his friends. He was sure of his strength and skill, but halfway up, a rock slipped beneath him. He tumbled down the mountainside, bruising and hurting himself badly. His pride had led him to ignore sage advice and he paid the price.

fable1: A tortoise, slowly crawling through the grass on a hot summerâ€™s day, called out to the birds flying overhead and asked if there was one among them who could teach her how to fly. A hawk heard her call and asked what he would get in return for taking her with him. The tortoise, eager to take to the skies, promised him all the riches of the Red Sea. The hawk agreed and carried the tortoise upwards in his talons. But, just as they reached the clouds, he suddenly let go of her and the tortoise fell towards the ground, eventually landing on the side of a mountain and shattering her shell. As she lay dying, the tortoise reflected that her fate was well-deserved: "Why did I dream of wings and clouds, when I can't even walk on the ground with ease?"
fable2: Once a peacock, envious of the nightingale's song, petitioned the forest king to replace his squawk with a melodious voice. The king obliged but warned him he would lose his beautiful plumage in exchange. The peacock, blinded by vanity, agreed. When his voice became lovely, he lost his vibrant feathers and became a grey bird, soon ignored by all, while the nightingale, still plain, remained beloved for her song.

fable1: A queen bee once visited Zeus to offer him some of the fresh honey from her hive. Delighted by her delicious offering, Zeus promised to grant her a single wish. After some thinking, the bee asked Zeus to give her a sting, so that she could attack anyone who comes too close to the hive. This saddened Zeus as he did not wish to introduce a new source of danger for his beloved humans, but bound by his promise he could not refuse the request.
