Thus, he gave the bee a sting, but also made it so that stinging anyone would cost the bee her life, since the sting would remain firmly stuck in her opponent.
fable2: Once, a spiteful snake made a wish on a shooting star to make the forest's waters poisonous, out of envy for the other animals who could drink while he could not. As the days passed, the other animals began to suffer, but so did he, as his food source started to diminish. In the end, he perished alone, a victim of his own poison.

fable1: A donkey was once driven along a busy street, carrying a famous image of a saint, to be placed inside the townâ€™s main church. As he moved along, bystanders bowed deeply before the image and prayed in accordance with religious customs. The donkey, however, assumed that the bows and prayers were directed at him and, filled with pride, refused to take another step. His driver, bemused by the animalâ€™s behavior, hit him with the whip, saying how ridiculous it would be for men to pray to a donkey.
fable2: Once, a small sparrow learned to build a nest by watching a skilled swallow. The sparrow proudly showed off its nest to all the birds in the forest, claiming it was an original design. But when a storm came, the sparrow's replica could not withstand the winds, revealing its true maker.

fable1: A young puppy used to sneak up on people and bite their feet. Due to his small size, he was difficult to notice and often caught people unawares. Thus, his master hung a chime around his neck, which would ring out with every step the puppy took. Not recognising its true purpose, the puppy grew proud of the chime and went to show it off around town. There, he encountered an older dog who said to him: "What are you doing? This chime of yours is not something to be proud of. On the contrary, it lets everyone know that you have been a bad dog."
fable2: Once, a mischievous crow loved to cause chaos in the peaceful forest. His loud caws and constant pranks instigated laughter from some, but irritation from many. One day, he saw the silent owl, always surrounded by respectful creatures, and mistook it for envy. Hoping to achieve the same, the crow caused even more havoc. Yet, the crowd around him never admired, only endured.

fable1: A fly landed on a ramâ€™s horn as he was grazing in a meadow and sat there for quite some time. As she was about to fly off, the fly asked the ram if he would like her to go or preferred that she stay longer. The ram replied: "I didnâ€™t notice when you arrived and I wonâ€™t miss you once youâ€™re gone."
fable2: Once, a boastful rabbit claimed he was the fastest in the forest, challenging everyone for a race. The slow tortoise, tired of his bragging, accepted the challenge. On the day of the race, the rabbit ran swiftly, leaving the tortoise far behind. But, assured of his victory, he decided to take a nap mid-way. When he woke up, he found the tortoise had already crossed the finish line, winning the race while he slept.

fable1: Two roosters living in the same farmyard were fighting for dominance over the rest of the farm chickens. Eventually, one emerged as the victor. The defeated opponent scurried away and hid in the shadow of a tree, while the winner paraded around the yard, crowing and spreading his wings. This drew the attention of a hawk flying overhead, who quickly descended on the loud rooster and carried him off in his talons. Seeing this, his opponent came out of the shadows and became the undisputed ruler of the yard.
fable2: Once, a proud rooster strutted around the barnyard, insisting he was the most important because he woke everyone up. One day, disdaining the hens, he crowed before dawn. The farmer, disturbed from sleep, mistook the crowing for a predator's call and shot the rooster to protect his flock.

fable1: Two oxen were dragging a heavily laden cart along a dusty country road. With every step the oxen took, the wheels of the wagon creaked in a strained and pitiful way. The oxen eventually turned around to address the wheels: "Dear wheels, why are you making such noise? After all, we are doing all of the work - if anyone should be complaining, itâ€™s us."
fable2: Once, there was a mighty lion who constantly roared about his minor scratches, demanding attention from all the animals in the jungle. Meanwhile, a frail deer with a broken leg limped silently in the shadows, never uttering a sound. The animals admired the deer's strength and shunned the lion's cries.

fable1: An old woman owned a single sheep and as the time came to shear him, she decided to do so herself to save some money. However, she was not skilled in this task and ended up shearing some of the sheepâ€™s flesh together with the fleece. In great pain, the sheep cried out: "What have I done to you to hurt me so, mistress? What value does my blood add to the wool? If you want my meat, take me to a butcher, as he at least will spare me unnecessary pain. But if you want my wool, take me to a shearer who knows his craft."
fable2: A farmer had a golden goose that laid one golden egg every day. One day, the farmer decided to cut open the goose to get all the eggs at once and save the daily grain fed to the goose. But upon opening the goose, he found no golden eggs inside, and his steady source of wealth was gone forever.

fable1: A sick bull was lying in a quiet corner of the farmyard, unable to move. One by one, his companions stopped by to ask about his well-being and each one took some of the food that was left for the bull by his owner. Eventually, the bull died - not of his sickness but of hunger.
fable2: Once, a naive frog befriended a cunning snake who promised to protect him from predators. Grateful, the frog welcomed the snake into his home. One day, he returned to find his family swallowed by the snake. The frog realized too late the true nature of his so-called friend.

fable1: "Little shrub, why donâ€™t you do as I do and raise yourself up to the skies?", asked the oak of the shrub that was growing nearby. The shrub replied: "I am happy with the way I am. Besides, while you are certainly mightier than I can ever hope to be, I think that I am safer." The oak laughed at the word of the shrub: "Safer? who could possibly threaten me or throw me to the ground?" Shortly after, a strong storm visited the forest and uprooted the oak, felling it without much effort. The shrub, on the other hand, bent to the storm, and stood upright once it passed.
fable2: A small mouse, living comfortably in an unnoticed crack within a grand palace, watched as a proud peacock strutted around the courtyard, his vibrant feathers drawing the attention of all. One day, a flock of hunters invaded, drawn by the peacock's magnificent display. While the peacock was captured by the hunters, the mouse remained safe in his unnoticeable home.

fable1: One evening, a goatherd was driving his flock towards the farm and noticed that a couple of wild goats had joined the flock during the day. Happy about the newcomers, he led them into the enclosure with the rest of the goats and closed it overnight. Next day, the goats were unable to go to the pasture due to a heavy storm, so the goatherd supplied them with hay for the day, giving the wild goats plenty of food to entice them to stay, while only giving just enough to the rest of the flock. The day after, just as the goatherd opened the enclosure to bring the goats to the pasture, the wild goats stormed out and ran away as fast as they could. Upset, the goatherd shouted after them, accusing them of ingratitude. The goats replied: "The very reason why we do not want to stay is that you gave us more food than your own flock! If we stayed and some new goats came along, you would treat us badly just to impress the new arrivals."
fable2: Once, a squirrel who had shared countless winters with a sturdy oak decided to leave for a blossoming cherry tree that promised sweeter fruits. The cherry tree, however, wilted at the first sign of snow, leaving the squirrel cold and hungry. Meanwhile, the sturdy oak stood tall, its branches bare, having given its last acorn to a loyal cardinal.

fable1: The lumberjack had felled an old redwood and, to split its trunk into pieces for transport, fashioned wedges from its branches. The redwood sighed with sadness - it was not as upset about having been felled, as it was about the fact that its own branches were used to break it apart.
fable2: Once upon a time, a proud lion, refusing to hunt, preferred to steal food from others. One day, he stole a honeycomb from a beehive. As he savored his stolen meal, he got stung painfully by the angry bees. His loud roars of pain echoed through the jungle, a self-inflicted torment for his own actions.

fable1: Having visited places all over the world, the traveller often bragged about different feats he performed during his travels upon his return to his hometown. Once, he claimed that he jumped so high into the air when visiting Tokyo that no other man could ever jump even half as high. To lend his words more credence, he followed up by saying that plenty of people in Tokyo could be called on as witnesses to his deed. One of the bystanders pointed out that this would not be necessary if the traveller just jumped right here in front of them, like he had done in Tokyo.
fable2: Once, a tiny Sparrow and a boastful Peacock had a flying competition. The Peacock flaunted his vibrant feathers and loudly claimed he was the superior bird. The Sparrow, silent and determined, flew swiftly, beating the Peacock. The Peacock, humiliated, sulked, while the Sparrow quietly returned to her perch, her victory speaking volumes.

fable1: A little bird discovered a juicy worm atop a leaf. However, she saw its larger shadow and thought it was bigger. She dove for the shadow, expecting a feast. But she ended up pecking only the darkened earth, while the real worm slithered away.
fable2: A badger, crossing a bridge over a river with a piece of meat in his teeth, saw his own reflection in the water and took it for that of another badger, with a piece of meat double his own in size. He immediately let go of his own, and attacked the other badger to get his larger piece. In the end, he lost both: that which he clawed at in the water, because it was a reflection; and his own, because the river swept it away.

fable1: Once, a small bird lived in a barren desert where no trees grew. Struggling under the harsh sun, the bird gathered pebbles, stuck them together with mud and built a tiny, dome-shaped house. Soon, other birds, awed by this shelter, followed suit. Before long, the barren desert was dotted with little dome homes, giving the bird population a chance to thrive.
fable2: A magpie dying of thirst saw a jug, and hoping to find water, flew to it with haste. When she reached it, she discovered to her grief that it contained so little water that she could not reach it. She tried everything she could think of to reach the water, without success. At last she collected as many small rocks as she could carry and dropped them one by one with her beak into the jug, until she could reach the water and prevent her own death.

fable1: A jackal found a magical stone that could change his fur into any color. Everyday, he'd change color to please his friends. One day he turned red for the fox, green for the parrot, and white for the rabbit. However, his friends grew tired of his inconsistency and soon left him, for they missed the unique grey jackal they'd once befriended.
fable2: A middle-aged man, whose hair had started graying, dated two women at the same time. One was younger, and the other older than him. The older woman, ashamed to be seen with a younger man, pulled out some of his black hairs whenever he came to visit. The younger, on the other hand, didnâ€™t want to become the wife of an older man, and removed every gray hair she could find. Thus he soon found himself without any hair left on his head.

fable1: Once upon a time, a greedy monkey incessantly stole bananas from other animals. Instead of sharing, he hoarded them all, his cavern growing full. One day, a landslide sealed the cavern entrance, trapping him inside. His only food? The rotten bananas his greed had amassed.
fable2: Two neighbours came before Zeus and asked him to grant them their wishes. Now, one of them was greedy, while the other was envious. To punish them both, Zeus granted that each might have whatever he asked for, but only if his neighbour had twice as much. The greedy one prayed to have a room full of gold. No sooner said than done; but all his joy turned to grief when he saw that his companion got two rooms filled with gold. The envious man didnâ€™t want his neighbor to have any joy at all and asked for one of his own eyes to be removed, so that his companion would go completely blind.

fable1: Once, in a forest, a wise old elephant pleaded with a mischievous monkey to stop stealing fruits from his tree. The monkey ignored the elephant's words, laughing and continuing his theft. Finally, the elephant, in frustration, shook the tree mightily, sending the monkey tumbling to the ground. From then on, the monkey never dared to steal from the elephant's tree.
fable2: Some storks chose a field newly sown with wheat as their new feeding ground. The owner of the field, for a while, scared them away by waving an empty sling. Once the storks found out that the sling was empty, they started to ignore the farmerâ€™s threats. In response, the farmer charged the sling with stones, killing dozens of the birds in quick succession.

fable1: Once there was a sparrow who desired to soar as high as an eagle. So, he left his family and friends to live among the eagles. But the eagles paid him no mind, for he was not one of them. Lonely and ignored, the sparrow returned home, realizing that his true happiness lay among his own kind.
fable2: A farmer covered his wheat field with nets in order to catch some of the storks who had been eating the freshly sown seeds. Among the storks, he also caught a robin, who broke his little leg. The robin asked the farmer to spare and release him. "Please let me go, as my broken limb is most pitiful and I am not a stork, but a robin - a good and honest bird. I love my father and mother and have a plumage quite unlike that of a stork." The farmer laughed at that, saying "This may all well be true, but I only know that I caught you together with the other thieves, and now you must perish together with them, as well."

fable1: Once, in a lush forest, lived a generous tree who gifted all his fruits to a greedy villager. The villager started selling the fruits, becoming rich and influential. With wealth and power, he craved more and convinced the tree to give him his branches and trunk too. The tree, hoping to help, agreed. However, once the villager had all he desired, he left the tree a lonely stump, useful to no one.
fable2: The horse and the moose had a fight, so the horse went to the woodsman and asked him for help in getting back at the moose. The woodsman agreed, saying: "If you want my help, I will have to place this iron between your jaws to be able to guide you with these reins. I must also saddle you, so that I can keep steady as we pursue your enemy." The horse agreed and was quickly saddled and bridled. After the moose was vanquished, the horse demanded that the woodsman remove the riding equipment, to which the woodsman replied that he prefers to keep the horse just as he is.

fable1: Once a proud peacock sat alone, basking in the grandeur of his colorful feathers. He ignored the other birds who sought his friendship, feeling he needed no one. Then winter came, stripping him of his splendid plumage and leaving him cold and lonely. The peacock sought the company of the other birds, but they had already formed their flocks. Alone, the peacock shivered.
fable2: A magpie, dying of illness, asked her father: "Father, do not mourn my death, but instead ask the gods to save me." He replied, "Which of the gods do you think will come to your aid? Is there one among them whose altar you havenâ€™t stolen shiny offerings from?"

fable1: Once, a mischievous fox constantly bragged about his countless victories over the lion to his fellow forest animals. One day, the lion overheard him and challenged the fox to a duel. The fox, trembling with fear, declined. The forest animals, realizing his deceit, laughed at his cowardice. From that day, the fox lived in shame and isolation, his lies having fooled no one but himself.
fable2: An ape, after surviving a shipwreck, encountered a turtle who offered to carry him to the shore. To pass the time, the ape told the turtle many fantastical stories, each of them filled with lies and exaggerations.  "I see you have quite the education ", said the turtle,  "unlike me, who didnâ€™t have much schooling." As the two entered a bay, the turtle asked the ape if he knew Herring Roads, by which the bay was commonly known. The ape thought the turtle meant a famous man and, not wishing to appear ignorant, said:  "Of course I know Rhoades - he is a old college friend of mine, who also happens to be my - " The turtle couldnâ€™t bear to hear any more lies and dove quickly underwater, causing the ape to vanish forever.

fable1: Once a boastful hare, known for his tall tales, claimed to outpace the wind. The animals, curious and doubtful, gathered to watch the race. When the race began, the hare sprinted as fast as he could while the wind barely stirred. But as the race progressed, the wind swiftly passed the hare before he could even realize it. The hare, panting and exhausted, couldn't meet his own claim, revealing the truth of his boastful tales.
fable2: A raccoon and an ape were travelling together along the same road. On their way, they passed through a cemetery full of statues. "All these statues," said the ape, "are made to honor my ancestors, who achieved great things in their day." The raccoon replied, "You have picked a most appropriate subject for your lies, as it would be difficult for any of your ancestors to disagree with your words."

fable1: In a tree-filled forest, a young sapling asked the mighty oak how to grow tall and strong. The oak merely pointed to its own gnarled trunk and spreading branches, and said nothing. Over time, the sapling observed the oak, copying its deep roots and broad leaves. Eventually, the sapling grew into a majestic tree, understanding the silent teachings of the oak.
fable2: A crab said to his daughter, "Child, why do you always walk so one-sided? It is far better to go straight forward." To which the daughter replied: "This may be so, father - why donâ€™t you show me how itâ€™s done and Iâ€™ll follow in your footsteps?" The father-crab tried and failed repeatedly, finally admitting to his daughter that he canâ€™t do it himself.

fable1: Once upon a time, a squirrel worked diligently all through autumn, stashing away food in his burrow. His neighbor, a grasshopper, laughed and spent his days in play, sparing no thought for the coming winter. Come the first snowflake, the squirrel was warm and content in his burrow, while the grasshopper was left cold and starving.
fable2: An angler, who was also a skilled musician, took his nets and his flute to the shore. There, he played a small concert for the fish, hoping that the music would compel them to dance into his nets that he laid below him in the water. After waiting for some time, he gave up and cast the nets into the sea, instead, catching plenty of fish in the process.

fable1: Once, a small sparrow admired the eagle soaring high in the sky and wished to do the same. The sparrow tried to fly higher than ever, ignoring its small wings. Unable to keep up, it fell into the sea, exhausted. Meanwhile, another sparrow gathered seeds happily, content under the clear blue sky.
fable2: A man had a donkey and a small Pomeranian dog. The donkey lived in a stable with plenty of oats and hay, but spent his days working at the mill and carrying heavy loads of wood from the forest to the farm. The Pomeranian, on the other hand, knew many tricks and was fondled by his master, who always gave him tasty treats. The donkey envied the life of the Pomeranian and one day decided to make his way into the masterâ€™s house, imitating the Pomeranianâ€™s tricks as best as he could. In doing so, he broke the masterâ€™s table and smashed his precious dishes to pieces. Seeing this, the servants quickly drove the donkey back into the stable, kicking and beating him with clubs all the way, nearly killing him.

fable1: Once a small bird's nest was blown away by a storm. The bird pleaded with the tree, the cloud, and the wind to help retrieve its nest, but each replied they couldn't undo what nature had done. So, with courage and determination, the bird started building a new nest. After many days of hard work, it finally completed a stronger and better nest.
fable2: A snipe had made her nest in the early spring on a recently sown wheat field. Her children have almost grown to their full size, when the owner of the field, looking over his by then ripened crop, said, "I will ask all my friends and neighbors to help me with the harvest." One of the young snipes asked his mother whether they should move to a new place for safety. "Not yet," she replied; "a man who only asks his friends to help him with the harvest does not have his mind fully set to it." A few days the farmer noticed the wheat to be heavy with grain and proclaimed: "Tomorrow, I will hire as many labourers as I can and harvest this wheat myself." Upon hearing these words, the snipe said to her children, "It is time for us to move -  a man who no longer trusts his friends, but will reap the field himself, will go through with his plans."

fable1: Once, a cunning fox made a promise to a trusting rabbit that he would not eat her. The rabbit, relieved, began to consider the fox a friend. However, when winter came and food was scarce, the fox ate the rabbit. As the rabbit took her last breath, she realized the naivety of her trust.
fable2: "Be quiet." said the nanny to the infant on her lap. "If you donâ€™t stop crying at once, I will give you to the coyote who will gobble you up." As it happened, a coyote passed by the window at just this moment. So he crouched down by the side of the house and waited until at last the infant began to cry again. Then, the coyote came forward before the window, and looked up to the nanny, wagging his tail in anticipation of his meal. But the nanny quickly shut down the window and called for help, so that the coyote ended up being chased away by dogs.

fable1: Once, a songbird with a beautiful voice lived in a forest. The animals admired her songs and she was adored greatly. One day, a squirrel requested the songbird to live near his home, promising her the best nuts in exchange for her daily melodies. The songbird agreed and started singing near the squirrel's home every day. After a few weeks, the squirrel got used to the bird's songs and started finding them annoying. He eventually drove the songbird away, unable to bear the once-admired melody.
fable2: When first the raccoon encountered the tiger he was very frightened, so he ran away and hid himself in the woods. Next time, however, he came near the tiger, but stopped at a safe distance, watching the majestic beast pass him by. The third time they came near one another the raccoon went right up to the tiger, asking him how his family were, and when they may come across each other again. Once their conversation was concluded, he parted from the tiger without much ceremony or reverence.

fable1: Once, a cunning fox boasted loudly in the forest, claiming he'd given up his thieving ways and became a vegetarian. He preached the importance of peaceful eating habits, while his mouth was still stained red from his last meal. Even though he had a gift for eloquence, the wise old stag just smiled and walked away, refusing to be swayed.
fable2: After being hunted down and wounded by a pack of dogs, the coyote lay sick and injured in his lair. Starving, he called to a goat who was passing by, begging him to get some water from a stream flowing nearby. "If you will bring me the water, I will be able to get myself some meat to help me recover.", the coyote said. "Yes," said the goat, "if I provide you with the water, Iâ€™m sure I will be the one providing you with the meat, as well."

fable1: Once a mighty lion was caught in a hunter's trap. A sly serpent, his rival, happened upon him and the lion, desperate, begged for his help. Moved by the lion's plight, the serpent fetched the key hanging nearby and freed the lion. The moment the lion was released, he pounced on the serpent, devouring him instantly.
fable2: A woodsman came into a forest, asking the trees there for a new ax handle. Agreeing to his request, the trees offered him a young birch. Having fitted the new handle, the woodsman quickly felled the largest trees in the forest. An old oak, realizing too late their mistake, commented: "Had we not given up the birch so easily, we could have continued standing here for ages."

fable1: Once a jackrabbit, notorious for his mischievous pranks, decided to play a trick on the wise old tortoise. He painted a rock to look like a large, juicy carrot and left it on the tortoise's path. The tortoise, finding the rock, realized immediately that it was a trick. In response, he painted a similar rock to look like a juicy lettuce leaf and left it where the jackrabbit would find it. As anticipated, the jackrabbit chipped a tooth on the rock, proving that sometimes the prankster becomes the pranked.
fable2: An elderly woman who lost sight in both of her eyes called a doctor, agreeing that if he cures her blindness, he would receive a generous payment; but should his treatment fail then he would get nothing. The doctor visited the woman several times, applying a healing salve to her eyes and stealing a little of her valuables on each visit. Once he took everything of value, he healed her and asked to be paid. The woman refused, having noticed that her valuables are missing. Angered, the doctor summoned the woman before a judge, where she argued: " It is true that I promised to pay the doctor once I recover my sight. He now declares that I am healed, but I claim that I remain blind. You see, before I lost my sight, I saw in my house various valuable items: but now, although the doctor claims to have cured me, I see none of my prized possessions."

fable1: A young wolf, eager to prove his strength, was convinced by a cunning fox to challenge the great bear. The fox insisted the bear was a coward and would surely run away. Trusting the fox's words, the young wolf challenged the bear and was swiftly defeated. As the fox scavenged the leftovers of the defeated wolf's meal, it was clear who had truly won.
fable2: A raccoon caught his tail in a trap, losing all of it but the stump in an effort to free himself. At first he was ashamed to face his kind, but then decided to embrace his fate. He summoned all the raccoons to a meeting, where he proposed that they should all remove their tails, as they were an inconvenience, making it harder to sit comfortably or run away from dogs. There was no advantage at all to having a tail, he argued.  "That is a nice speech," said one of the older raccoons; "but I doubt that you would make the same bold proposal if you still had your tail."

fable1: Once upon a time, in a dense woodland, a mighty oak tree and humble bamboo lived side by side. One stormy night, a violent wind shook the woods fiercely. The proud oak stood tall against the wind, refusing to bow, and eventually broke. The bamboo, on the other hand, bent with the wind and survived unscathed.
fable2: A huge tree was felled by the wind and thrown across a river. It fell among some weeds and asked them: "How are you, despite being so light and weak, not completely crushed by these strong winds?" The weeds replied, "You fight the wind, and are destroyed for that very reason; we bend before it and escape undamaged."

fable1: Once, a rabbit found companionship in a cunning fox. The fox, always with a smile, promised protection from predators. One day, the rabbit discovered a fox fur near his burrow and a trace of his missing sibling. His heart filled with doubt, the rabbit distanced himself from the fox, forever questioning the truth behind the fox's gleaming teeth.
fable2: A coyote spotted a rabbit on the hillside and ran after her for some time. As he closed in on the rabbit, he would sometimes bite her as if intending to kill her, and playfully fawn at her at other times. Finally, the rabbit told the koyote: "I wish that you would show your true colors. Why do you bite me with such force, if you are my friend? And if you are my enemy, why do you fawn at me?

fable1: Once a snake found a cave filled with gold. Blinded by the glitter, it coiled around the treasure, refusing to leave even for food. Over time, the greedy snake grew weak and starved, still wrapped around the gold it could never use.
fable2: One day a farmer found a huge, yellow egg next to one of his ducks that was as heavy as led. Assuming that someone was playing a trick on him, he initially wanted to throw it away. But he decided to take it home with him, after all, and soon realized that it was made of pure gold. He found a new egg every morning and soon became very rich by selling them. The richer he got, the more greedy he became, until he finally decided to get all the gold at once by killing the responsible duck. But, having killed and opened her, he found nothing inside.

fable1: In a dense forest, a beaver spent his days tirelessly building a dam. Other animals lounged lazily, teasing him for his non-stop work. One day, a flash flood hit. The animals took shelter in the beaver's strong dam. Astonished and grateful, they praised the beaver's diligence that had unknowingly saved their lives.
fable2: A father, on his dying bed, wanted his children to give the same attention to his land as he himself had. Thus, he called them to his bedside and told them of a great treasure hidden in one of his vineyards. Once he had passed, his children carefully dug over every portion of their land. While they found no treasure, the vines produced a superabundant crop thanks to their labour.

fable1: In a quaint forest, a mischievous monkey purposely dropped a ripe banana between an elephant and a rhino. Both large beasts claimed it as their own and soon, a ferocious fight broke out. The monkey watched from a tree, laughing at their foolishness. However, when the elephant and rhino realized they were tricked, they teamed up and chased the monkey out of the forest. The monkey learned that instigating trouble can have dire consequences.
fable2: A drummer who led on the soldiers during their battles with his music, was captured by the enemy. He begged his captors to spare him: "I have not slain a single man of your troop. I have no arms, and carry nothing other than this one drum." "We are putting you to death for this very reason," they replied; "as it was your drum that inspired others to take up arms against us."

fable1: Once, a hare and a tortoise decided to race again. The hare, confident in his speed, spent the day playing, while the tortoise steadily plodded on. As the sun began to set, the hare realized he had little time left and blamed the tortoise for setting a slow pace. Despite his complaints, it was the tortoise who crossed the finish line first.
fable2: A pilgrim about to set out on a long journey noticed his mutt standing at the door and stretching himself. Thus, he asked the mutt: "Why do you stand there doing nothing? Everything is ready but you, so come with me without any more delay." The mutt, wagging his tail, replied: "But master, I have been ready for some time and have been waiting for you."
